title: El FMI y el BM llegan a su reunión de primavera con los aranceles como telón de fondo - (Published 17 hour(s), 31 minute(s) ago)
content: La directora gerente del FMI, Kristalina Georgieva y el presidente del BM, Ajay Banga, han advertido ya de que la incertidumbre y la volatilidad actual provocarán un avance del PIB más lento, por lo q ...
resumen:
El Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI) y el Banco Mundial (BM) inician sus reuniones de primavera en un contexto marcado por la guerra arancelaria impulsada por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, y por el impacto que esta tendrá en la economía.

La directora gerente del FMI, Kristalina Georgieva, y el presidente del BM, Ajay Banga, han advertido que la incertidumbre y la volatilidad actual provocarán un avance del Producto Interior Bruto (PIB) más lento, por lo que urge llegar a acuerdos rápido.

Las próximas proyecciones económicas globales del FMI “incluirán reducciones notables” en cuanto a crecimiento, “pero no recesión”, y también “alzas en las previsiones de inflación para algunos países”.

El FMI publicará su informe de previsiones, conocido como WEO, el Monitor Fiscal y el Informe de Estabilidad Financiera Global.

La volatilidad de los mercados financieros ha aumentado y la incertidumbre en torno a la política comercial es descomunal.

Los encuentros privados y los foros públicos de debate que se llevarán a cabo hasta el día 26 en Washington abordarán temáticas como la creación de empleo o la gestión de la deuda.

En la próxima década se espera que en los países en desarrollo se incorporen al mercado laboral 1.200 millones de jóvenes, unos 780 millones más con respecto a los nuevos puestos previstos para entonces.

La historia demuestra que las economías más abiertas tienden a crecer más rápido y a resistir mejor las fluctuaciones de las reservas y las crisis.

Estados Unidos es el principal accionista tanto en el FMI como en el BM y hay dudas sobre si el país seguirá contribuyendo a sus iniciativas, como el compromiso de 4.000 millones de dólares para la Asociación Internacional de Fomento (AIF) que el año pasado firmó su antecesor, el demócrata Joe Biden (2021-2025).

title: Ataques de Trump contra la FED hunde a las bolsas - (Published 7 hour(s), 49 minute(s) ago)
content: El S&P 500 (.SPX) perdió 2.36%, el Nasdaq Composite retrocedió 2.55% y el promedio industrial Dow Jones cayó 2.47%. Las bolsas asiáticas terminaron la jornada con pérdidas al igual que las europeas.
resumen:
El S&P 500 (.SPX) perdió 2.36%, el Nasdaq Composite retrocedió 2.55% y el promedio industrial Dow Jones cayó 2.47%. Las bolsas asiáticas terminaron la jornada con pérdidas al igual que las europeas.

Trump intensificó hoy sus críticas contra el titular de la Fed, Jerome Powell, a través de redes sociales, calificándolo de "gran perdedor" y exigiendo que baje las tasas de interés de forma inmediata.

Un nuevo capítulo de desplome de las bolsas de valores aconteció hoy, luego de que el presidente Donald Trump intensificara sus ataques contra el presidente de la Reserva Federal, Jerome Powell, poniendo en riesgo la independencia del banco central.

La onza de oro ya supera los US$3,400 por incertidumbre de guerra comercial.

Los tres principales índices bursátiles de Estados Unidos registraron fuertes pérdidas y el grupo de acciones tecnológicas de gran capitalización conocido como los “Siete Magníficos”, presionaron al Nasdaq, centrado en tecnología.

El S&P 500 (.SPX) perdió 2.36%, el Nasdaq Composite retrocedió 2.55% y el promedio industrial Dow Jones cayó 2.47%. Las bolsas asiáticas terminaron la jornada con pérdidas al igual que las europeas.

La Bolsa de Valores de Lima (BVL) cayó 0.67%, el paquete de acciones peruanas que cotiza en la BVL (ETF EPU) cayó 0.02%. De similar forma, la Bolsa de Santiago cerró en -0.82% y la Bolsa de Colombia en –0.43%. Sin embargo, México y Brasil cerraron al alza.

“La caída está relacionada con las tensiones políticas y la incertidumbre comercial y financiera. El detonante fue el ataque de Trump al presidente de la FED. Esa presión, el mercado la interpretó como amenaza directa a la independencia del banco central. Con ello, la pausa de 90 días de los aranceles no logró calmar a las empresas e inversores”, comentó César Huiman, analista senior de equity research de Renta4 SAB.

“La BVL descendió alrededor de 0.67%, explicado principalmente por el desempleo negativo de los mercados financieros internacionales, dadas las renovadas críticas del presidente Donald Trump hacia el presidente de la Reserva Federal, Jerome Powell, y a las tensiones comerciales en curso, lo que ha generado incertidumbre entre los inversionistas”, dijo por su parte Silvana Caro, analista de Estrategia y Análisis de Inteligo SAB.

Trump intensificó hoy sus críticas contra el titular de la Fed, Jerome Powell, a través de redes sociales, calificándolo de "gran perdedor" y exigiendo que baje las tasas de interés de forma inmediata.

“Con estos costos bajando tan bien, tal como predije que lo harían, casi no puede haber inflación, pero sí puede haber una DESACELERACIÓN de la economía, a menos que el señor Demasiado Tarde, un gran perdedor, baje las tasas de interés, YA”, escribió Trump en Truth Social refiriéndose a Powell.

El asesor económico de la Casa Blanca, Kevin Hassett, dijo el viernes que el presidente y su equipo seguían evaluando si podían destituir a Powell, un día después de que Trump afirmara que el despido del presidente de la FED “no puede llegar lo suficientemente rápido”, exigiéndole un recorte de tasas.

La FED ha jugado un rol importante en la economía mundial, debido a su papel en la estabilización económica y la regulación de la política monetaria. Sus decisiones sobre las tasas de interés y la oferta monetaria pueden impactar las economías de otros países, ya que muchas monedas y mercados están vinculados al dólar.

La independencia del banco central es importante porque permite asegurar la estabilidad de precios al permitir decisiones monetarias basadas en análisis técnicos en lugar de presiones políticas a corto plazo, lo que a su vez genera mayor credibilidad y confianza en la economía. Bancos centrales independientes han demostrado históricamente una gran capacidad para gestionar la inflación.

title: Trump vs. Powell - (Published 14 hour(s), 30 minute(s) ago)
content: “Si se diera la salida de Powell, se materializaría un fuerte remezón en el escenario político y en los mercados financieros”, escribe María Rosa Villalobos, editora de Economía y Día1.
resumen:
María Rosa Villalobos escribe sobre Trump vs. Powell.

El presidente de la FED afirma que los datos apuntan a una ralentización económica en EE.UU. en el primer trimestre.

Donald Trump ha pedido reiteradas veces y públicamente a Jerome Powell que baje las tasas de interés de referencia en Estados Unidos.

El mandatario ha discutido en privado y ya por varios meses la posibilidad de despedir a Powell antes de que termine su mandato en mayo del próximo año.

Powell no está dispuesto a renunciar si el presidente Trump se lo pidiera, según dijo él mismo el último noviembre.

La destitución de altos funcionarios de la FED no está permitida por ley.

El presidente Trump insinuó el último jueves que perseguiría este objetivo, asegurando que la salida del director del banco central estadounidense “no puede ser lo suficientemente rápida”.

Existe un caso en la Corte Suprema estadounidense que podría determinar si los presidentes pueden despedir a los jefes de agencias independientes como la FED.

En los últimos meses la administración Trump ha impulsado la destitución de altos funcionarios en otras instituciones.

Si se diera la salida de Powell, se materializaría un fuerte remezón en el escenario político y también en los mercados financieros.

title: Trump can’t keep China from getting AI chips, TSMC suggests - (Published 17 hour(s), 50 minute(s) ago)
content: As the global artificial intelligence (AI) race presses on amid a US-China trade war, the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC)—a $514 billion titan that manufactures most of the world's ...
resumen: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), a $514 billion company that manufactures most of the world's AI chips, is warning that it may not be possible to keep its customers' most advanced technology out of China's hands amid a US-China trade war and the global artificial intelligence (AI) race. US export controls require chipmakers to monitor shipments and know their customers to restrict China's access to AI chips. TSMC confirmed in its 2024 report that its "role in the semiconductor supply chain inherently limits its visibility and information available to it regarding the downstream use or user of final products that incorporate semiconductors manufactured by it." TSMC expects that it plays too big a role in the semiconductor industry to stop all the possible unintended end-uses of the semiconductors it manufactures. It appears impossible to track all the third parties determined to skirt sanctions. In October, a research firm called TechInsights took apart an AI accelerator from China-based and US-sanctioned Huawei and found that TSMC had produced the AI chip made by Nvidia that powered the product, Bloomberg reported. TSMC increasingly risks sanctions for failing to comply with export controls, even if it seemingly has nothing to do with its customers diverting shipments into China. TSMC promptly notified US officials of the feared national security risk, confirming that one of its customers' chips "might have been diverted to a restricted entity or incorporated into a restricted entity’s product," TSMC's report said. There currently appears to be no perfect solution to deter recurring violations. "Despite TSMC’s best efforts to comply with all relevant export control and sanctions laws and regulations, there is no assurance that its business activities will not be found incompliant with export control laws and regulations," TSMC said. "If TSMC or TSMC’s business partners fail to obtain appropriate import, export or re-export licenses or permits or are found to have violated applicable export control or sanctions laws, TSMC may also be adversely affected, through reputational harm as well as other negative consequences, including government investigations and penalties resulting from relevant legal proceedings," TSMC warned. TSMC's report said it is thriving despite years of tariffs and export controls, with at least one analyst suggesting that, so far, the company appears "somewhat tariff-proof." US President Donald Trump announced in 2025 an intention to impose more expansive tariffs on imports into the United States, TSMC said. "Any tariffs imposed on imports of semiconductors and products incorporating chips into the United States may result in increased costs for purchasing such products, which may, in turn, lead to decreased demand for TSMC’s products and services and adversely affect its business and future growth," TSMC said. If TSMC's business is rattled by escalations in the US-China trade war, that risks disrupting the entire global semiconductor supply chain. Trump's semiconductor tariff plans remain uncertain. About a week ago, Trump claimed the rates would be unveiled "over the next week," Reuters reported. Industry estimates suggest that tariffs could cost chipmakers more than a billion dollars over the next year, Reuters reported. China's increased restrictions on access to the raw materials TSMC needs to manufacture chips could spike costs, TSMC said. "Any increase in the use of export control restrictions and sanctions to target certain countries and entities, any expansion of the extraterritorial jurisdiction of such measures, or complete or partial ban on semiconductor products sales to certain entities could impact not only TSMC’s ability to continue supplying products to those customers, but also our customers’ demand for our products, and could even lead to changes in semiconductor supply chains," TSMC warned. Trump's semiconductor tariffs will be based on the results of a probe into potential impacts on national security and the economy. TSMC's annual report warned that fines for non-compliance are a top emerging risk, along with risks of building new fabs and potential claw-backs or disruptions in government incentives (like the CHIPS Act, which Trump claims he wants to gut or cut). TSMC's "operations have not been materially affected by the expanded export control regulations or the novel rules or measures adopted to counteract them," TSMC said. "Nevertheless, depending on future developments in global trade tensions, such regulations, rules, or measures may have an adverse impact on the Company’s business and operations, and TSMC may incur significant legal liability and financial losses as a result."

title: Kentucky needs a new trade policy, not Trump's chaotic tariff war | Opinion - (Published 22 hour(s), 17 minute(s) ago)
content: The broad tariff policies President Trump rolled out will raise consumer prices, harm Kentucky industries and hurt the nation's trade deficit.
resumen:
President Trump's tariffs aim to address public anger over trade policies, but their broad application will harm the economy and consumers.

Kentucky lost significant manufacturing jobs due to trade imbalances exacerbated by NAFTA and China's WTO entry.

Targeted tariffs and industrial policies focused on strategic sectors are a better approach.

Fruit of the Loom apparel plants once dotted the Kentucky landscape, with 11,000 workers at factories in Jamestown, Frankfort, Campbellsville, Franklin, Greensburg, Princeton and Bowling Green. In 1987, the company was the state’s second-biggest manufacturer. But over time, Fruit of the Loom began closing plants and moving production to lower-wage countries like Honduras, Haiti and Vietnam. By 2014, all production in the state was gone.

Between 2000 and 2010, Kentucky lost a net 100,000 manufacturing jobs in total, one-third of what we had 10 years earlier. The state lost an estimated 45,400 net jobs directly from the China shock and at least 12,100 from NAFTA. Especially hard hit was employment in computer and electronic parts, metal products and machinery, apparel, furniture and textiles.

The us-against-the-world nature of the tariffs and the bullying trade war stance are already hurting U. S. exports that are facing retaliatory tariffs in industries like Kentucky bourbon.

title: Trump team needs a trade deal to stop investor panic - (Published 7 hour(s), 36 minute(s) ago)
content: Dan Ives, the veteran tech analyst for Wedbush, put it this way: “The White House needs trade deals done quick with a negotiation path established with China otherwise the markets, 10-year yield, USD, ...
resumen: About 10 days ago, Scott Bessent began telling Wall Street executives that he was on the verge of removing the big dark cloud hovering over the US markets and economy: The Treasury Secretary said he was making significant progress in cutting trade deals with India, Japan, South Korea, and Australia. The markets would love the move; President Trump could move forward with his broader plans of isolating China, with its high tariffs and frequent theft of US intellectual property. He would avoid an existential threat to his young presidency in a tariff-induce economic meltdown that could lead to rampant inflation and a recession. President Trump meeting in the Oval Office with Japanese Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy Ryosei Akazawa on April 16, 2025. But that was last week, and there are still no deals — at least none that look imminent by press time Monday — which is why the markets resumed trading after the weekend in free fall. It didn’t help that Trump added to the uncertainty, when he called Fed Chair Jerome Powell a “major loser,” more than hinting that he will try and remove him over his reluctance to cut interest rates because tariffs might stoke inflation. Stocks fell more than 2%, depending on the index. The Dow crashed 1,200 points at one point, bond yields spiked, and other more ominous signs: A flight not to US treasuries or the dollar but gold and Bitcoin. Dan Ives, the veteran tech analyst for Wedbush, put it this way: “The White House needs trade deals done quick with a negotiation path established with China otherwise the markets, 10-year yield, USD, Gold, and the economy will head down their own divergent paths over the coming weeks and months ahead.” Businesses have held back from announcing layoffs amid the uncertainty because, as one institutional investor put it, “Trump might be able to pull this off,” and cut favorable trade deals. Japan was thought to be close to getting a deal, but then nothing happened. One top investor said he was told by a Japanese trade official that the White House keeps fiddling with the exact terms. The White House believes that Japan along with the other nation’s on Bessent’s list have been slow to remove protectionist trade barriers for US goods. Wall Street believes messaging is still a problem. The more trade centrist Bessent appears to be spearheading the efforts, but Trump’s voluble and hawkish Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick remains in the trade meetings along Jamieson Greer, the US trade ambassador. All three were in last week’s White House confab with the Japanese trade minister Ryosei Akazawa. Peter Navarro, the uber hawkish Trump trade guru is always in the mix. “In the end, it doesn’t matter what Bessent thinks or does because he works for Trump,” one banker who deals with the White House told me.

title: U.S. farmers were already struggling to turn a profit. Trump's trade war will make that harder - (Published 22 hour(s), 23 minute(s) ago)
content: The U.S. trade war with China is coming at a tough time for American farmers, who are already dealing with lower crop prices and higher costs for farm necessities. Tariffs are likely to push crop ...
resumen:
U.S. farmers were already struggling to turn a profit. Trump's trade war will make that harder.

Glenn Brunkow, who grows corn and soybeans near Westmorland, Kansas, said it’s a pretty tough time. The prices for farm necessities have risen much faster than the price of the soybeans and corn that Brunkow grows. The cost of big tractors is up close to 300% over 30 years, according to Farm Credit Services of America. Supply chain issues have also pushed prices up for other farm inputs like fertilizer and diesel fuel.

China was buying about a quarter of the U.S. soybean crop. When Trump slapped a 145% tax on Chinese imports, China struck back with a 135% tariff on U.S. soybeans.

Doug Meinhardt, the parts program manager at KanEquip, a chain of farm equipment dealerships primarily in Kansas, has noticed parts prices jerking skyward faster than normal, and he’s bracing for big price hikes on heavy equipment.

Vance Ehmke, who grows wheat, rye, and a forage crop called triticale in western Kansas, believes that U.S. agriculture was in recession before the trade war. Ehmke said that U.S. farmers have spent decades carefully nurturing lucrative trade relationships with foreign buyers.

Trump dipped into the treasury, spending $23 billion to compensate farmers for the damage caused by a much smaller trade war. He’s pledged to provide more of the same this time.

title: Ishiba says Japan won’t just keep conceding in US tariff talks - (Published 22 hour(s), 12 minute(s) ago)
content: TOKYO: Japan won't just keep conceding to US demands to reach a deal over tariffs, Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said, in some of his most combative remarks since President Donald Trump launched a ...
resumen:
Japan won’t just keep conceding to US demands to reach a deal over tariffs, Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said.
Ishiba made the remarks since President Donald Trump launched a push for more access to Tokyo’s sensitive auto and agricultural sectors as part of his global trade war.
Ishiba said in parliament on Monday (April 21), "If Japan concedes everything, we won’t be able to secure our national interest.”
Tokyo is working to hammer out its strategy for a second round of negotiations before the end of April after its chief negotiator held initial talks with US officials in Washington last week.
Trump frequently complains about the lack of American cars in Japan.
Senior US officials have also highlighted tariffs on agricultural imports into Japan, including rice, as examples of unfair trade barriers.
Cars are Japan’s most lucrative export industry and the nation’s farmers are an important support base for his ruling Liberal Democratic Party, which faces a national election in July.
A survey published Monday in the Asahi newspaper showed approval for Ishiba’s cabinet at 30% and disapproval at 56%.
Ishiba launched a strong defence of barriers to agricultural imports.
Ishiba said, "We have been working to protect Japanese agriculture using various methods, such as tariffs and minimum access rules.”
Ishiba said, "We must continue to protect it, and of course, we must also protect consumer safety.”
Japan needs to find bargaining chips as it seeks to win an exemption from an across-the-board US tariff rate of 24% that was reduced to 10% for 90 days from earlier this month.
Japan also faces a 25% levy on shipments of cars, steel and aluminum.
Some local newspapers reported that Japan may offer to increase imports of US rice and soybeans, and potentially relax safety standards for imported cars as proposals to move tariff talks forward.
Ishiba said on Monday that he didn’t expect left-hand drive US cars to sell much in Japan, where cars travel on the left-hand side of the road.
Ishiba didn’t mention specific offers that Japan would make, but he ruled out a scenario in which he would sacrifice farmers by lowering protections for their products as part of any deal to get the 25% tariff on autos lifted.
Trump has also raised the financial contribution Tokyo makes to support US military bases in Japan as an issue of concern, including before a meeting with Japanese trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa last week.
Ishiba said Tokyo won’t simply raise its cost burden for the US military presence.
He added that he won’t rush to visit Washington in the coming days to strike a deal with Trump.

content: Farmers from across Canada weighed shared perspectives on the upcoming 2025 federal election. In part one, they talk Trump, tariffs and trade tensions.

Glacier FarmMedia reporters and contributors from Ontario, Quebec, Alberta and Manitoba asked farmers about their election priorities, how represented by the federal government they’ve felt — and finally, if there’s anything they’d like farmers from other regions to understand about the issues they face.

Ontario:
*   Embro area dairy producer Braydon Older said, “We’ve got a bully right now. And he’s got (Canadian supply-managed agriculture) in his sights,” referring to Donald Trump.

Quebec:
*   Christian Hébert, an apple and raspberry producer near Deschambault, west of Québec City, and also a Bloc Québécois’ candidate for the riding of Portneuf-Jacques Cartier, said the pandemic, climate change and now economic war with the United States have compounded the burdens on farms.
*   He said this year he’s seeing even more farms going out of business.

Alberta:
*   Bryan Perkins, who owns a mixed pig and grain farm operation in the municipal district of Wainwright in east-central Alberta, said the on-again, off-again rollercoaster of U.S. tariffs is putting a strain on the industry.
*   Phil Constantin, a grain grower in Sturgeon County north of Edmonton, said that although the U.S. tariff situation is harmful to the Canadian agriculture industry, he believes that President Trump is only standing up for his country.

Manitoba:
*   Scott Peters, a hog farmer near Steinbach in southeastern Manitoba, said tariffs were the top concern.
*   Harley Siemens, an egg producer in south-central and southeastern Manitoba, said they are concerned that the supply-managed sectors stay in place.

title: China and Brazil to discuss expanding farm exports amid US tariff escalation with Beijing - (Published 20 hour(s), 8 minute(s) ago)
content: Brazil has emerged as a beneficiary from existing Chinese tariffs on US farm imports, which have pushed Beijing to seek new agricultural suppliers. As US exports to China shrink, Brazil is filling the ...
resumen: Senior Brazilian and Chinese agriculture officials are to meet in Brasília this week to discuss ways to expand Brazil’s exports to Asia’s largest economy. The meetings will focus on Brazilian exports of agricultural products, such as soybeans and beef, and “how to address the gap left by US tariffs”. Other topics to cover are expanding Brazil’s harvest and accrediting Brazilian slaughterhouses for export to China, following Beijing’s recent rejection of 28 local plants because of technical and sanitary issues. Brazil’s Agriculture Minister Carlos Favaro and a Chinese delegation led by Zhang Zhili, the vice-minister of agriculture and rural affairs, are to take part in the meetings, scheduled for Thursday and Friday. They will take place against the backdrop of unprecedented trade tension between China and the US. US President Donald Trump vowed to protect American soybean farmers from his trade war with Beijing. China hiked its levies on imports of all US goods to 125 per cent. The Chinese delegation to Brazil was already poised for meetings related to the Brics working groups – Brazil will host this year’s Brics summit in July in Rio de Janeiro. Brazil has emerged as a beneficiary from existing Chinese tariffs on US farm imports. Brazil is filling the gap as US exports to China shrink. Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva deals with domestic pressure to manage growing food exports without increasing inflation. The talks will cover China’s new 10-year agricultural development plan. The scheme calls for boosting technological innovation and productivity in agriculture, expanding self-sufficiency in food production, and increasing domestic grain and meat output. Brazilian officials hope to develop supplements to the plan. Brazil “wants to understand how to align with the plan by adding value to its own exported grains” and seeks ways to process soybeans and corn domestically before shipping them in containers. Brazilian agriculture officials have proposed increasing expertise exchange in the sector, including joint research with China in areas like artificial intelligence, biotechnology and digital crop management. Larissa Wachholz, a former adviser on Chinese relations to Brazil’s Ministry of Agriculture and a researcher at the Brazilian Center for International Relations, said the meeting offered an opportunity for Brazil to underscore its reliability as a supplier. Wachholz warned that Brazil must also prepare for scenarios where the two superpowers reconcile. Wachholz also noted that the recent rejection of several Brazilian slaughterhouses was part of a broader debate within China. Domestic producers were lobbying Beijing to preserve local competitiveness and limit overreliance on imports. Lula’s visit to China in May to take part in the China-CELAC Forum and the Brics summit in July create momentum for positive outcomes. Brazil’s storage infrastructure remains a bottleneck, with a deficit of around 120 million tonnes in grain capacity. Chinese capital could help fill the gap.

U.S. farmers were already struggling to turn a profit. Trump's trade war will make that harder.
The U.S. trade war with China is coming at a tough time for American farmers, who are already dealing with lower crop prices and higher costs for farm necessities.
Tariffs are likely to push crop prices further down, while increasing the costs for fertilizer and farm equipment.
Glenn Brunkow grows corn and soybeans near Westmorland, Kansas.
The prices for farm necessities have risen much faster than the price of the soybeans and corn that Brunkow grows.
The cost of big tractors is up close to 300% over 30 years, according to Farm Credit Services of America.
Supply chain issues have also pushed prices up for other farm inputs like fertilizer and diesel fuel.
In recent years, dry conditions have cut production in parts of the Great Plains and Midwest.
China was buying about a quarter of the U.S. soybean crop.
Trump slapped a 145% tax on Chinese imports, China struck back with a 135% tariff on U.S. soybeans.
Trump’s import taxes are starting to exacerbate inflation on farm equipment.
Doug Meinhardt is the parts program manager at KanEquip, a chain of farm equipment dealerships primarily in Kansas.
Parts Program Manager Doug Meinhardt has noticed parts prices jerking skyward faster than normal, and he’s bracing for big price hikes on heavy equipment.
The 1980s farm crisis triggered the shakeout in the tractor industry, consolidating production under a handful of global corporations that divvied it up across three continents.
Vance Ehmke grows wheat, rye, and a forage crop called triticale in western Kansas.
U.S. agriculture was in recession before the trade war.
Farmers’ exports are threatened by retaliatory tariffs.
Trump issued a post on his Truth Social social media platform last month telling farmers to get ready to sell more food “INSIDE” the U.S.
U.S. farmers have spent decades carefully nurturing lucrative trade relationships with foreign buyers.
Trump dipped into the treasury, spending $23 billion to compensate farmers for the damage caused by a much smaller trade war.
He’s pledged to provide more of the same this time.
Glenn Brunkow is sticking with Trump.

title: Trump effect: How tariffs, trade wars will affect global property market - (Published 16 hour(s), 24 minute(s) ago)
content: Since the return of Donald Trump to the White House at Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington, the world economy has not ...
resumen: Since the return of Donald Trump to the White House, the world economy has not remained the same due to his protectionist economic policies. Trump’s tariffs on major export commodities have created trade wars impacting international trade and the world economy. In March 2025, Trump imposed tariffs on imports from Canada, Mexico, and China (10 percent on Canadian energy, and doubled the tariff on Chinese goods from 10 percent to 20 percent). These countries retaliated, leading to global trade tensions. These tariffs and trade tensions are creating upsets in the economies of some countries, including Nigeria. Analysts believe Nigeria is not totally insulated from the overall effect. Bismarck Rewane, CEO, Financial Derivatives Company, says the tension in the global economy will affect Nigeria in many ways. Rising global commodity prices pose upside risk to inflation. Investors may delay commitments due to global economic uncertainties and interest rate shifts; higher global interest rates could increase Nigeria’s external debt burden while global demand slowdown could weigh on Nigeria’s non-oil exports, especially agriculture and manufacturing. Global economic trends impact remittances, a key source of forex for Nigeria; Nigerian stock and bond markets face contagion risk from the global financial markets; fluctuating global oil prices could impact Nigeria’s foreign earnings and fiscal stability, and government revenue may fall short, straining budgets and public spending. Real estate analysts posit that these impacts have potential shocks for the sector, especially as over 70 percent of building materials used in Nigeria are imported mostly from China. Remittances are one area that the local real estate market would be affected significantly. Kunle Adeyemi, CEO, Sterling Homes, stated that over 30 percent of market transactions is driven by the activities of Diaspora investors. At the global level, higher material costs may drive up prices with Trump’s 25 percent tariffs on all steel and aluminum entering the US, with ‘no exemptions, and no exceptions.’ His tariffs on Mexico and Canada are also set to hit softwood lumber and concrete. The construction industry is highly sensitive to material costs, and tariffs could significantly impact building expenses. This may lead to increased costs for residential and commercial developments, potentially reducing new construction activity. Another area of impact is in monetary policy divergence which could influence activity. Analysts reason that the impact of tariffs on inflation and economic activity could lead to diverging monetary policy approaches among the world’s central banks. This, in turn, could affect financing. Trump’s tariffs are driving up inflation in the US, potentially forcing the Federal Reserve to maintain higher interest rates which will make mortgages and real estate financing more expensive, possibly dampening housing market activity and reducing affordability for buyers. As global trade tensions escalate, the real estate market faces a period of heightened uncertainty. Investors and developers must navigate shifting demand dynamics, rising construction costs, divergent monetary policies, and currency fluctuations. For those looking to invest in property, understanding these macroeconomic trends will be critical.

Schumer noted it's estimated that the average person in America could have seen as much as $100,000 of loss in their retirement accounts because of Wall Street volatility tied to the tariff announcements.

Schumer declared that when the Senate returns, they will force a vote on a resolution to end Trump's tariff war once and for all. title: Trump’s tariffs overshadow IMF and World Bank meetings - (Published 10 hour(s), 18 minute(s) ago)
content: The men and women who run the global economy will arrive in Washington this week for the spring meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank with one goal: get out of town without ...
resumen:
The spring meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank are taking place in Washington this week. The main goal for those involved is to avoid President Donald Trump's attention. Trump's plan to raise U.S. import taxes to their highest level in over a century is a major question overshadowing the global economy, but it is not on the official program. In February, Trump ordered a review of U.S. support for all international organizations, which extended to the fund and bank. The Heritage Foundation's "Project 2025" report called for the United States to withdraw from both financial organizations. Ajay Banga, president of the World Bank, stated they are having a constructive dialogue with the U.S. administration.

On April 9, one week after announcing a 10 percent tariff on almost all foreign-made goods plus higher import taxes on dozens of U.S. trading partners, Trump paused the most onerous levies, saying he would negotiate them with more than 70 nations. Trump set a 90-day deadline for results and began preliminary talks with Japan, India, and South Korea. The president’s 25 percent tariffs on steel, aluminum, automobiles, and auto parts remain in place, and he has promised to impose still more levies on pharmaceutical products and semiconductors. The average U.S. tariff rate has increased from 2.4 percent to near 25 percent. Douglas Rediker, managing partner of International Capital Strategies, said this is the most seismic change to the global economy and geopolitics in our lifetimes. U.S. negotiators, led by Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, are focusing on the 15 largest economies. Trump said he was confident of reaching quick agreements, including with the European Union.

Nearly $6 trillion in global stock value evaporated over the past month. Analysts at Citigroup Global Markets cut their 2025 global growth estimate by half a percentage point. Global trade flows are expected to shrink this year after growing by nearly 3 percent in 2024. The world economy will grow at an annual rate of 2.2 percent, its slowest pace since the pandemic collapse in 2020. Kristalina Georgieva, the International Monetary Fund’s managing director, said the organization will mark down its global growth forecast. The European Central Bank cut its main policy rate by a quarter percentage point to 2.25 percent, with ECB President Christine Lagarde saying the outlook for growth has deteriorated owing to rising trade tensions. South Korean officials introduced a supplementary budget plan of more than $8 billion. Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba is considering a potential stimulus package of tax cuts or direct cash payments that could be worth almost $100 billion.

Trump’s aim to slash U.S. imports in favor of greater domestic production would put pressure on China and Germany. China has taken retaliatory measures against the U.S., ordering a halt to exports of rare earth minerals. Andy Rothman, CEO of Sinology LLC, said the government really just wants to wait and see how bad things get. Carsten Brzeski, global head of macro research for ING in Frankfurt, said the Trump tariffs just aggravate and enhance the already well-known European problems.

Alan Wolff, the WTO’s former No. 2 executive, said Trump’s actions over the past three months have hurt U.S. diplomatic credibility. New Zealand Prime Minister Christopher Luxon proposed expanding an existing 12-nation trade pact to include the European Union.

title: Trump tariffs part of a longer-term trend - (Published 16 hour(s), 39 minute(s) ago)
content: From early in World War II, the United States led a broad movement toward freer trade that has been the foundation of our unprecedented postwar prosperity. That may be changing. President Donald Trump ...
resumen: The European Union decided to its proposed 50% tariff on American whiskey. President Donald Trump’s tariff moves are distinctively dramatic but are part of a longer-term trend. Protectionism has been growing since the last phase of the Obama administration. Hillary Clinton and others ultimately opposed the Trans-Pacific Partnership treaty. The TPP and the similar Transatlantic Free Trade Area were sidelined. In 2011, Congress ratified free trade agreements with Colombia, Panama and South Korea. Approval was timed to coincide with the visit of South Korean President Lee Myung-bak. The largest bilateral trade agreement in history ended tariffs on more than 90% of trade categories between the two nations. The current Doha Round, expanded to include developing nations, is stalled by vexing agricultural issues separating Africa and Europe. In 1944 at Bretton Woods, N.H., the Allies hammered out the post-war economic structure, to operate under the United Nations — the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, formed in 1948, became the World Trade Organization in 1995. The original United Nations vision was in the Atlantic Charter, announced by British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and President Franklin D. Roosevelt. The uncertainty of tariffs, combined with all the other unpredictable activities and decisions of the Trump administration, presents major challenges for the network of alliances of the United States. Adam Smith’s classic “The Wealth of Nations” was published in 1776. Trump’s tariffs recall an earlier period. Arthur I. Cyr is the author of “After the Cold War — American Foreign Policy, Europe and Asia.”

title: Markets Slide as Trump Renews Attacks on Fed Chair - (Published 11 hour(s), 15 minute(s) ago)
content: President Trump’s pressure on the Federal Reserve, on top of the uncertainty about his tariff policy, continued to jar investors as stocks, bonds, oil and the U.S. dollar all tumbled.
resumen:
Stocks slumped, bonds sold off and the U.S. dollar continued to lose ground on Monday as President Trump renewed his attacks on Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve.

Wall Street began the day with a slump, but the sell-off gained steam after Mr. Trump targeted Mr. Powell in a social media post, calling him “a major loser” and urging the Fed to cut interest rates. Mr. Trump also suggested that an economic slowdown would be Mr. Powell’s fault.

After a late recovery, the S&P 500 dropped 2.4 percent for the day. All of the major sectors in the index fell, with the technology, energy and consumer discretionary sectors hardest hit.

The Trump administration has acknowledged an uptick in the probability of a recession.

Mr. Trump had also lashed out at Mr. Powell last week, saying to reporters on Thursday that “if I want him out, he’ll be out of there real fast — believe me.”

A day earlier, the Fed chair had warned in a speech that tariffs could create a “challenging scenario” by putting the central bank’s two main goals — stable inflation and a healthy labor market — in tension.

The yield on 10-year Treasury notes jumping above 4.4 percent as investors sold the bonds.

The U.S. dollar continued its slide against nearly every other major currency on Monday. It fell about 1 percent against the euro, to the lowest level in more than three years. The dollar also fell against the Japanese yen, to its lowest level since September.

Since Mr. Trump’s announcement of tariffs against nearly every U.S. trading partner on April 2, the S&P 500 has fallen roughly 9 percent. The benchmark is about 16 percent below its closing high in mid-February.

The customs office said on Monday that exports to the United States fell more than 14 percent in the first 20 days of April, versus the same period last year.

The International Monetary Fund has warned that its latest projections for the global economy, to be released on Tuesday, will forecast slower growth and higher inflation this year than previously anticipated.

Oil prices dropped nearly 2 percent on Monday, with Brent crude at about $66.67 a barrel. Oil has dropped about 20 percent from its mid-January high.

China has several significant economic levers at its disposal: Its control over its currency, the yuan, domination of the rare Earths market, and ownership of US Treasury bonds. China still relies heavily on the American market to sell its products. China holds a significant portion of the US national debt. The US government funds its spending by issuing Treasury bonds, which are bought by investors. The US national debt is now over $36 trillion. China, in 2024, held an average of $772.5 billion in Treasury bonds, is the second-largest foreign US debt holder, just behind Japan. This represents about 2% of the US public debt.

title: Steel and aluminum tariffs are keeping auto suppliers up at night - (Published 17 hour(s), 48 minute(s) ago)
content: The 25% tariffs cover the metals themselves and a list of “derivative” products made of foreign steel and aluminum, including many auto parts. Importers must determine the foreign steel or aluminum ...
resumen: The Trump administration's steel and aluminum tariffs are causing significant concern for auto suppliers. The 25% tariffs cover the metals themselves and "derivative" products made of foreign steel and aluminum, including many auto parts. Importers must determine the foreign steel or aluminum content in those products, which is taxed at 25%. The list of tariffed products is expected to grow. Nearly $150 billion in goods are subject to the steel and aluminum derivative tariffs across 289 product categories. Automotive products subject to the derivative tariffs include aluminum door hinges, bumper parts and body and suspension components. Importers of those products are required to pay a 25% tariff only on the value of the foreign steel or aluminum in the products. Those duties stack on top of the 25% auto parts tariff scheduled to go into effect by May 3. Calculating the value of the aluminum and steel in those products can be a complicated process. Suppliers need visibility deep into their supply chains. Smaller suppliers might lack the resources to monitor the latest tariff developments and to calculate sourcing figures. Duties must be paid on the value of the entire part if the value of the foreign steel or aluminum content is unknown. Trump’s executive orders also direct the agency to assess penalties if the steel and aluminum values are listed incorrectly. Trump’s executive orders direct the Commerce Department to establish a process for including additional derivative products by May 11.

title: Probability of a US recession in 2025 is 90%: Torsten Slok, Apollo Chief Economist - (Published 19 hour(s), 55 minute(s) ago)
content: The top finance experts, economists, and hedge fund managers, have expressed concerns about the potential risk of recession.
resumen: Torsten Slok, Apollo Chief Economist, believes that if current policies do not change, the probability of a US recession in 2025 is 90%. Slok believes that tariffs have been implemented in a way that has not been effective, and there is now a 90% chance of what can be called a Voluntary Trade Reset Recession. JP Morgan’s CEO Jamie Dimon recently forecast a 50% possibility of a U.S. recession by 2025. Nouriel Roubini believes the US economy will avoid a recession while the Fed keeps interest rates constant for the rest of the year as tariff-related policy debates de-escalate. Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates, expressed concern about a potential recession. Moody’s Analytics Mark Zandi predicts the US could face a recession within three to four weeks. Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers thinks that the Trump tariff might result in the loss of 2 million American jobs. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent is of the view that Trump’s sweeping levies were necessary. Allianz’s Chief Economic Advisor, Mohamed El-Erian, said he believed the U.S. economy would expand by between 1% and 1.5% this year. Goldman Sachs economists stated Wednesday afternoon that a recession is no longer the base case, with a 45% probability of recession. Bank of America’s CEO Brian Moynihan predicts no recession this year. Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase suggest a 40% and 60% chance of a recession, respectively. National Economic Council director Kevin Hassett predicts no recession in 2025.

title: Thailand faces hit from US-China trade war - (Published 8 hour(s), 7 minute(s) ago)
content: Economists are voicing concerns over escalating tension between the US and China, saying Thailand cannot avoid the indirect repercussions of global trade uncertainty that could strain the country's ...
resumen:
Thailand faces a hit from the US-China trade war. Global tensions are likely to affect Thai trade. The article was published on April 22, 2025, in the Business section, written by Nareerat Wiriyapong.

Allianz SE states that the indirect repercussions of global trade uncertainty are expected to strain the country's export sector and supply chains.

Economists are voicing concerns over escalating tension between the US and China.

Nattawat Onratn, senior executive vice-president at CGS-CIMB Securities, said the ongoing trade war could last for a year. He also noted that a short-term rebound of the Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) could be seen but the bourse overall would remain under the negative influence of Trump's tariff policy.

Allianz SE said Thailand is likely to face moderate impacts from the US-China trade war, with GDP growth expected to slide to 2.2% this year and 2.1% in 2026, from 2.5% in 2024.

Ludovic Subran, chief investment officer and chief economist at Allianz, said the reciprocal tariff has raised global trade costs, particularly affecting the automotive, manufacturing, and electronics sectors. He also noted that the indirect repercussions of global trade uncertainty are expected to strain the country's export sector and supply chains.

Thailand's central bank is likely to adopt monetary easing policies, while domestic policy support and trade diversification will be crucial in cushioning the impact.

Allianz anticipates global GDP growth might drop to 2.3% in 2025, the lowest since the Covid-19 pandemic. Key drag factors include policy uncertainty, slowing consumption in developed countries, and geopolitical tensions.

The Asia-Pacific region is forecast to grow by 3.9% in 2025.

BofA Global Research said that considering the headwinds to growth from the US tariff uncertainty, Thailand may need additional fiscal stimulus.

Pipat Luengnaruemitchai, emerging Asia economist, said that any additional stimulus would require another law to authorise further borrowing.

content: The capital of Guangdong province in the south of the country is a major manufacturing center; many of its factories have suspended shipments to the US ...
resumen: Guangzhou, the capital of Guangdong province in southern China, is a major manufacturing center. The city is experiencing the impact of Donald Trump's tariffs. Lily Liao, owner of Guangzhou Dawang Garment, a textile factory, reported that her orders from U.S. businesses fell from about $100,000 a month before Trump took office to zero. Eight other Chinese factories in the city reported being forced to suspend shipments. Mr. Wang, founder of Guangshen, a Panyu-based maker of ice cream and smoothie machines, stated that this is the first time in his 21 years in the business that he has stopped all shipments to the United States, which accounts for between 10% and 15% of his sales. Freight rates from China to the United States fell 64% between the last week of March and the first week of April. Lily Liao had to reduce her business with the U.S. by 70% when Trump unleashed his first tariff fury in 2018. The second set of tariffs has closed her channels to the U.S. She estimates she has lost 25% of turnover since last year. Her factory employs around 60 permanent workers who earn between 4,000 and 10,000 yuan a month ($548 and $1370). In Panyu, there are more than 7,200 garment-making companies and another 27,000 selling garments. Customs duties will apply to small shipments valued at up to $800 starting May 2. At a family-run shop specializing in button sewing, managers report a 20% drop in orders; at another, dedicated to elastic pleats, they report a 50% drop in orders since last year. Luo Weijun, a migrant from Jiangxi province, noticed a 5% drop in orders. In the province of Canton, with a population of 126 million, there are almost 74,000 industrial companies with a turnover of more than 20 million yuan ($2.7 million). Tracy, a Chinese woman in Sector A of the Canton Import and Export Fair, stated that "China is going to win." Longhua, a company with more than 500 employees, has suffered a considerable blow: the United States represents nearly 43% of its sales, more than $39 million. When tariffs surpassed 80% last week, almost all of its customers in that country asked for a pause in shipments. Steven Selikoff, 55, an experienced trader, stated that this is the best time to visit China.

title: - (Published 10 hour(s), 8 minute(s) ago)
content: Uncertainty surrounding the Trump administration’s tariff policy—which has shifted almost daily in recent weeks—has spooked markets, economists and consumers. But it hasn’t rattled Wilbur Ross, who ...
resumen:
Wilbur Ross, former Secretary of Commerce between 2017 and 2021, discusses tariffs in Trump's trade war 2.0.

Ross states there are "real differences" between the tariff policies implemented by Trump during his first and second terms.

During the first administration, the focus was on ensuring compliance with legislation to withstand court challenges, particularly regarding steel and aluminum tariffs. The administration prevailed in these cases.

The administration also used the IEEPA, which was also tested and worked.

In the second term, Trump has expanded the targets and objectives for tariffs beyond just trade, including raising revenues to offset tax cuts and using tariffs for diplomatic purposes like controlling fentanyl, controlling the border, and getting countries to increase defense contributions.

A new concept is putting a minimum tariff on everything for the whole world, which was not part of the program during the first term.

Ross believes that China never lived up to the "Phase One" deal. He emphasizes the importance of enforcement in any new deal with China.

He believes Trump's strategy is to isolate China and deal with them as a separate entity, with a more punitive attitude.

China has appointed a special, senior person for negotiations and requested to be treated with more respect.

Ross doubts that the current tariffs will harm the U.S. economy because other countries cannot afford a trade war with the U.S. due to their smaller size and greater reliance on trade with the U.S.

He notes that 70 countries have expressed interest in negotiating mutual downward movement in tariffs.

The semiconductor industry is sounding very patriotic and wants tariffs structured to avoid loopholes for China.

The Commerce Department is conducting a detailed study with public hearings and industry consultation.

Ross believes that the main concern investors have is the lack of clarity on how the tariffs will end.

He believes it's important that the tax bills be passed to protect the economy from any negatives from the tariffs.

content: China accused the US of weaponizing tariffs to pressure other countries into cutting trade with Beijing and vowed to "take countermeasures in a resolute and reciprocal manner" against countries that ...
resumen: China accused the US of weaponizing tariffs to pressure other countries into cutting trade with Beijing and vowed to "take countermeasures in a resolute and reciprocal manner" against countries that made deals against Beijing's interests. China's Commerce Ministry stated that the United States has abused tariffs on all trading partners under the banner of so-called 'equivalence', while also forcing all parties to start so-called 'reciprocal tariffs' negotiations with them. US stocks sank on Monday as multinational companies seek clarity on tariff policy while Trump continued to express irritation with Fed Chair Jerome Powell. Trump sounded upbeat about China trade talks last week, saying a “very good deal” was in the works. The president also hinted at easing tariffs to protect US consumers and cited progress in talks with other countries. China has shown openness to trade talks with the US, contingent on specific conditions, despite the White House clarifying that "China now faces tariffs of up to 245% on imports to the United States.". China raised its duties on imports of US goods to 125% from 84%, while US tariffs on Chinese imports have ballooned — to "a 125% reciprocal tariff, a 20% tariff to address the fentanyl crisis, and Section 301 tariffs on specific goods, between 7.5% and 100%.". US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told Yahoo Finance on Tuesday that he was optimistic about "clarity" on tariffs and progress on key trade deals. Trump has signaled a possible delay to auto levies after suspending duties on some consumer tech, even as he insists these tariffs will eventually come to fruition. The baseline 10% tariff that went into effect on April 5 remains in place for all affected imports into the US. Stocks tanked Monday as the tariff backdrop continues to unsettle markets. The S&P 500 was down more than 2.3%, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq sank 2.5%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped almost 2.4%, or nearly 1,000 points. All S&P 500 sectors were firmly in the red as President Trump's threats to Fed independence and the "Liberation Day" tariff regime fueled the "sell America" trade. Tesla (TSLA) and Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) are set to report quarterly results this week and provide updates on whether tariffs will hamper their outlooks. President Trump is scheduled to meet with executives at several major US retailers, including Walmart (WMT), Home Depot (HD), Lowe's (LOW), and Target (TGT). The Monday meeting will focus on the impact of Trump's tariffs on the retailer's businesses. Delta (DAL) CEO Ed Bastian said the company is in "constant communication" with the Trump administration over how its business is doing. The four retailers named all source a sizable portion of their products from China, which currently has a 145% tariff rate on exports entering the US. Vice President JD Vance visited New Delhi, India, on Monday for trade talks with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The pair discussed a deal to reduce India's tariff burden as well as defense, critical technologies, and energy. Mexico’s President, Claudia Sheinbaum, said she and President Trump have not yet reached an agreement after the two spoke last week about US tariffs on some of Mexico's goods. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) is planning to open a restaurant in Mexico early next year, its first location south of the border in its 30-year history. China's ambassador to the United States, Xie Feng, pressed for "peaceful coexistence" between the two nations, even as a trade war continues to escalate. Trump has raised tariffs on Chinese goods to 145%, and China has retaliated with duties of 125% on goods from the US. Beauty (ELF) has relied on sourcing from China to keep prices low for its value-oriented beauty offerings. About 80% of the company's products come from China, which are now subject to a 245% tariff rate. Over the past year, e.l.f. stock has crashed 68%. L'Oréal (OR.PA) CEO Nicolas Hieronimus said that the company has been working at reducing the exposure of NYX to Chinese imported products, which is now around 20%. Two Boeing (BA) 737 Max jets intended for Chinese airlines flew back to the United States over the weekend. China significantly cut imports of various US goods last month, with some categories seeing zero imports. South Korea and the US will kick off trade negotiations this week. Secretary of Treasury Scott Bessent and Trade Representative Jamieson Greer will meet with South Korea’s Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok and Industry Minister Ahn Duk-geun in Washington at 8 am local time Thursday. China issued a sharp warning on Monday over reports that the US is pressuring other nations to curb trade with Beijing in exchange for tariff exemptions. China vowed to work with like-minded countries to resist such bullying tactics and defend the integrity of the global trade system.

title: It’s Been Canada’s Weirdest Federal Election - (Published Apr 20, 2025)
content: The weirdest federal election in Canadian history is entering the home stretch, presenting a binary choice to voters in just a week’s time. According to virtually all the polling, that choice is ...
resumen:
The federal election is entering the final week, presenting a choice between Liberal Mark Carney and Conservative Pierre Poilievre. Polling indicates a Liberal lead of five to seven points, with the latest Nanos Research survey showing Carney leading Poilievre by six points. Several polls project a Liberal majority government of between 178 and 189 seats. The Conservatives had a 25-point lead a few months ago.

Carney's focus is on fiscal prudence and standing up to a U.S. president, while Poilievre emphasizes the negative aspects of the Liberals' record. Carney's pitch involves decisive actions, standing up to Trump, and transforming Canada, including counter-tariffs and free trade. Poilievre's appeal is for Canadians to remember the negative aspects of the Trudeau era, focusing on affordability.

Nik Nanos stated that voters believe Carney is best qualified to handle trade and tariff negotiations with the United States. The Poilievre campaign is betting that the tariff issue will fade, but it hasn't happened.

The leader-versus-leader contest between Poilievre and Carney was a wash. The NDP is in danger of losing party status, and some voters are parking their votes with Carney to prevent the Conservatives from forming government.

Carney has had an open-door policy with the press, while Poilievre has avoided scrutiny. Poilievre banned reporters from his campaign plane and avoided public events. Some Conservative candidates are also avoiding interviews and public events. Harrison Lowman reports that Conservative candidates have been "unofficially" forbidden from participating in debates in their ridings.

title: ‘Bridge to recession’: Duke international relations professors explain effects of Trump tariffs on Chinese goods - (Published Apr 20, 2025)
content: The implementation of Trump’s fluctuating trade policies this spring has caused the U.S. to cross the “bridge to a recession,” according to Professor of Political Science Joseph Grieco, who ...
resumen: President Donald Trump announced a universal 10% tariff on nearly all goods imported to the United States April 2, set to take effect April 5. One week later, he paused the measure. As of April 15, a 25% tariff on certain Canadian and Mexican goods and a 145% tariff on Chinese imports remain. Trump has been a fan of tariffs for decades, and they have been a central tool of his economic agenda. In his 2024 campaign, he touted tariffs as a strategy to reduce trade deficits, pressure trading partners across the globe and protect American industries and jobs. The implementation of these fluctuating trade policies this spring has caused the U.S. to cross the “bridge to a recession,” according to Professor of Political Science Joseph Grieco. Grieco clarified that the current economic situation does not yet constitute a global trade war. The relationship between the U.S. and China tells a different story. The two countries are locked into and have pursued a strategy of reciprocal, retaliatory impositions of higher and higher tariffs. In response to the U.S. tariff — originally 125%, then redefined as 145% when taking a prior policy into account — China imposed its own 125% tariff on American imports. Grieco predicted one to two more rounds of escalation of “punitive actions” besides tariffs before tensions between the nations cool off. Grieco suggested that Trump’s broader strategy is to pressure American companies operating in low-wage countries to relocate their manufacturing operations to the U.S. By incentivizing companies to move back home, these tariffs aim to “strengthen the international economic position of the United States and protect American workers” while reducing reliance on foreign powers. Grieco acknowledged Trump’s end goal is a “rational objective,” in practice, the U.S. faces significant obstacles to reshoring production. Higher labor costs, stricter environmental regulations and a relatively limited industrial workforce all drive up the cost of manufacturing domestically. The U.S. has comparative advantages in services such as finance and tech and [artificial intelligence], and China has comparative advantages in manufacturing. Clara Park, visiting assistant professor of political science, pointed to “cheaper inputs [and] labor” as factors driving that cost down. According to her, tariffs on foreign production ultimately hurt the very industries where the U.S. excels. The AI industry, for example, depends heavily on imported parts such as semiconductors and raw materials like steel to build data centers. But those inputs are now subject to increased import taxes, making production more expensive. The inconsistency of U.S. trade policy and tariff implementation makes prospects for U.S. reshoring even more uncertain. Grieco also noted that unpredictable policies, alongside strained relations with Ukraine and the E.U., have created “distrust and disenchantment” with some of the U.S.’s closest allies, leading to a loss of global trust in the U.S. as a stable economic force. Typically, when the stock market declines, investment in U.S. treasury bonds rises. According to Park, these bonds are considered the “safest assets on Earth because [they’re] backed by the U.S. government, which will almost never default.” But despite this, bond markets are now experiencing divestment, and the dollar is falling in value. These tariffs are a kind of consumption tax on average Americans. As prices rise on everyday consumer products, services like car and home insurance will also become more expensive. According to Grieco, a path forward can be found by reversing course: China could increase its imports of U.S. agricultural goods, while the U.S. could in turn increase imports of “middle-level area” consumer electronics — such as iPhones — that currently face heavy tariffs. Alternatively, he suggested “a mutual reduction in tariff rates” with a “side agreement” to open up more Chinese manufacturing facilities to operate within the U.S., fostering greater economic collaboration. Park proposed a greater emphasis on fields the U.S. excels in rather than competing head-on with China in manufacturing. This includes doubling down on sectors like technology, health care, finance and other areas driven by “human capital.” Grieco believes it is possible these tariffs set into motion a “long-term trend” that could be “accelerated.”

title: Una «bomba atómica» arancelaria - (Published Apr 20, 2025)
content: Usamos cookies en nuestro sitio web para brindarte la experiencia más relevante recordando tus preferencias y visitas repetidas. Al hacer clic en "Aceptar todo", acepta el uso de TODAS las cookies. Ta ...
resumen: Estados Unidos ha desatado una ola de choque en la economía mundial. El impacto de esa contraofensiva podría compararse con el «momento Nixon» de 1971, o con el «momento Reagan». Es imposible entender el «momento Trump» de la guerra arancelaria sin tener en cuenta la presión que ejercen más de cuarenta años de crónicos y gigantescos déficits comerciales y fiscales que son el talón de Aquiles de Estados Unidos. En 2024, el déficit comercial de Estados Unidos rondaba los 918.400 millones de dólares, mientras que el déficit fiscal alcanzaba los 1,8 billones de dólares. La deuda pública es de 36 billones de dólares y solamente el pago de intereses consumirá 1 billón de dólares. El Producto Interno Bruto (PIB) de Estados Unidos ascendía para esa fecha a 29,16 billones de dólares, todavía un 26,5 % del total mundial, pero en declive. El orden de Bretton Woods dio paso a la creación del Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI). Entre 2001 y 2005, América Latina se vio convulsionada por una ola revolucionaria. La crisis mundial de 2007/08 fue una señal de que la financiación tenía límites inevitables. Estados Unidos emite la moneda de reserva mundial sin respaldo y sin reglas. La superioridad de Estados Unidos se impuso en el mundo porque ese privilegio fue decisivo para mantener una maquinaria bélica que hacía las veces de «paraguas atómico» que protegía a la Tríada. Desde la crisis de 2007/08 y la transición de Bush hijo a Barack Obama, hasta el primer mandato de Donald Trump, Estados Unidos ha practicado la estrategia del QE ( Quantitative Easing ). El choque arancelario de Donald Trump tiene como objetivo explícito internalizar las cadenas de producción. China está comenzando a desdolarizarse por el medio de la articulación de los BRICS. China mantiene ya un sistema de pagos en su propia moneda con Rusia. La sobrevaloración del dólar hizo que los costos de producción fueran muy elevados en Estados Unidos. Donald Trump tiene un plan y su estrategia es coherente con ese plan. Donald Trump ha roto con la Organización Mundial del Comercio (OMC), el Tratado de París y hasta con la Organización Mundial de la Salud (OMS), y desafía a la OTAN y las Naciones Unidas. También promueve abiertamente una ofensiva nacional-imperialista neocolonial. Irán y Venezuela se verán amenazados. México se salvará relativamente porque es una semicolonia con un estatus privilegiado. Estados Unidos apuesta por la recuperación de una mayor cohesión social interna en el país y por la industrialización de sectores estratégicos. El «momento Trump» será muy grave, quizás peor que las contraofensivas de Richard Nixon y Ronald Reagan, y ello por tres razones. La primera es que supone la existencia de un liderazgo neofascista en la Casa Blanca. La segunda es que nos enfrentamos a una crisis medioambiental inevitable, respecto de la cual Donald Trump es un negacionista. La tercera es que China no parece dispuesta a dar marcha atrás y ceder al chantaje. La ofensiva de Donald Trump se apoya internamente en una corriente supremacista blanca, misógina y homófoba. La respuesta de China será decisiva ante una carrera armamentista que ya se ha puesto en marcha en Europa contra Rusia, un incidente inminente con Irán y la perspectiva de una amenaza a la soberanía de Venezuela. El declive histórico de Estados Unidos ha engendrado un monstruo.

content: Ciudad de México, 20 abr (EFE).- La televisión abierta mexicana ha comenzado a transmitir anuncios que promueven la política migratoria del presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, en horarios de máxi ...
resumen: La televisión abierta mexicana ha comenzado a transmitir anuncios que promueven la política migratoria del presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, en horarios de máxima audiencia. El comercial se transmite desde inicios de abril en medios nacionales durante partidos de fútbol y programación estelar. En el anuncio, se observa a la secretaria de Seguridad Nacional de Estados Unidos, Kristi Noem, quien pide a los migrantes abstenerse de entrar a su país de manera ilegal. Noem dice en el video: «Permítanme dar un mensaje del presidente Trump al mundo: si estás considerando entrar a Estados Unidos ilegalmente, ni siquiera lo pienses». «Si vienes aquí y violas nuestras leyes, te perseguiremos. Los delincuentes no son bienvenidos en Estados Unidos». Noem critica que «por mucho tiempo un liderazgo débil» de otros gobiernos han dejado abiertas sus fronteras, «inundando» sus comunidades «con drogas, tráfico de personas y criminales violentos», pero -afirma- que con Trump «esos días han terminado». «Si intentas entrar ilegalmente, serás atrapado, serás expulsado y nunca volverás. Sigue la ley y encontrarás oportunidades. Si la rompes, encontrarás consecuencias». Noem se reunió a finales de marzo pasado con la presidenta mexicana, Claudia Sheinbaum, en Ciudad de México, donde dialogaron sobre migración e inseguridad. La secretaria estadounidense afirmó que -durante la reunión- le solicitó a Sheinbaum reforzar la frontera con Guatemala y compartir datos biométricos de migrantes y viajeros con las autoridades de Estados Unidos, pero la presidenta mexicana negó haber firmado un acuerdo al respecto. A inicios de febrero, para evitar los aranceles de Trump, México lanzó la ‘Operación Frontera Norte’, con la que las autoridades mexicanas han incautado más de 24 toneladas de droga, que incluyen 129,24 kilogramos de fentanilo, según reportes de la Secretaría de Seguridad y Protección Ciudadana (SSPC) a inicios de abril.

content: China on Friday struck back at President Trump's ballooning tariffs, raising its duties on imports of US goods to 125% from 84%. The countermeasures will come into effect Saturday, further ...
resumen: China accused the US of weaponizing tariffs to pressure other countries into cutting trade with Beijing and vowed to "take countermeasures in a resolute and reciprocal manner" against countries that made deals against Beijing's interests. China's Commerce Ministry stated that the United States has abused tariffs on all trading partners under the banner of so-called 'equivalence', while also forcing all parties to start so-called 'reciprocal tariffs' negotiations with them. US stocks sank on Monday as multinational companies seek clarity on tariff policy while Trump continued to express irritation with Fed Chair Jerome Powell. Trump has hinted at easing tariffs to protect US consumers and cited progress in talks with other countries. China has shown openness to trade talks with the US, contingent on specific conditions, despite the White House clarifying that "China now faces tariffs of up to 245% on imports to the United States.". China raised its duties on imports of US goods to 125% from 84%, while US tariffs on Chinese imports have ballooned — to "a 125% reciprocal tariff, a 20% tariff to address the fentanyl crisis, and Section 301 tariffs on specific goods, between 7.5% and 100%.". US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told Yahoo Finance on Tuesday that he was optimistic about "clarity" on tariffs and progress on key trade deals. Trump has signaled a possible delay to auto levies after suspending duties on some consumer tech, even as he insists these tariffs will eventually come to fruition. The baseline 10% tariff that went into effect on April 5 remains in place for all affected imports into the US. Stocks tanked Monday as the tariff backdrop continues to unsettle markets. The S&P 500 was down more than 2.3%, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq sank 2.5%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped almost 2.4%, or nearly 1,000 points. All S&P 500 sectors were firmly in the red as President Trump's threats to Fed independence and the "Liberation Day" tariff regime fueled the "sell America" trade. A global e-commerce and logistics firm estimates that the airfreight industry could lose out on $22 billion in revenue if current US tariff policies continue. President Trump is scheduled to meet with executives at several major US retailers, including Walmart (WMT), Home Depot (HD), Lowe's (LOW), and Target (TGT). The Monday meeting will focus on the impact of Trump's tariffs on the retailer's businesses. Delta (DAL) CEO Ed Bastian said the company is in "constant communication" with the Trump administration over how its business is doing. The four retailers named all source a sizable portion of their products from China, which currently has a 145% tariff rate on exports entering the US. Vice President JD Vance visited New Delhi, India, on Monday for trade talks with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi as the Trump administration looks to complete trade deals with its top trading partners during the 90-day additional reciprocal tariff pause. Mexico’s President, Claudia Sheinbaum, said she and President Trump have not yet reached an agreement after the two spoke last week about US tariffs on some of Mexico's goods. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) is heading to Mexico and is planning to open a restaurant in Mexico early next year. China's ambassador to the United States, Xie Feng, said this weekend that "the earth is big enough to accommodate both China and the US," and pressed for "peaceful coexistence" between the two nations, even as a trade war continues to escalate. title: India and the new world disorder - (Published Apr 20, 2025)
content: Opening Pakistan’s borders could revive textiles, cement, and agriculture, tapping into the billion-plus market next door.
resumen: The escalating United States-China rivalry is reshaping the global order. India is leveraging its market size and reforms to grow its global clout, while Pakistan faces economic challenges. Globalisation is unravelling as a populist Trump pursues a neo-isolationist path. Deglobalisation is inherently inflationary. Tariffs indicate a deeper economic dislocation. Opening Pakistan’s borders could revive textiles, cement, and agriculture. The US-China trade war has intensified, with China halting exports of key rare earths. Economist Lawrence Summers warns that tariff-driven chaos risks “economic instability”. India continues to be the fastest-growing major economy. The US-China rift has driven multinationals to diversify supply chains, and India has lured giants like Apple. In 2023-24, Foxconn and Wistron produced $14 billion in iPhones, with Apple aiming to shift 25 per cent of its global output to India by 2027, up from 5pc in 2020. Foreign direct investment (FDI) equity inflows reached $44.4bn in FY24. The US is deepening ties with India, viewing it as a strategic counterweight to China. Bilateral trade hit $129.2bn in 2024, with India exporting $87.4bn and importing $41.8bn. The Quad alliance (US, India, Japan, Australia) counters China’s Indo-Pacific ambitions. US investments in India’s tech and defence sectors cement this partnership. India’s trade with China reached $118.4bn in FY24, skewed towards imports ($101.7bn) over exports ($16.67bn). Initiatives like “Make in India” and Digital India have propelled IT exports past $200bn in 2024, with mobile phone exports at $15bn, aided by US tariffs on Chinese goods (29pc in 2025). India’s 570 million internet users drive its digital economy, the world’s third-largest by purchasing power parity. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) projects 7pc GDP growth through 2030. India’s 3pc share of global manufacturing in 2023 trails China’s 32pc. India’s tariffs, raised to shield local industries, align with deglobalisation’s rise. India is negotiating missile sales to Southeast Asia, advancing the Middle East Europe Economic Corridor, and balancing US and China ties. Pakistan’s story contrasts starkly. The China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) delivered infrastructure projects, but these came at a steep cost. Trade with Beijing hit $20bn in 2024, dwarfing $7.7bn with the US. Pakistan’s economy faces steep challenges. Textiles, 60pc of exports, struggle with high energy costs and outdated tech. FDI declined to $1.8bn in 2023-24, compared to India’s $44.4bn. The World Economic Forum ranks Pakistan 107th in competitiveness. World Bank’s Martin Raiser warned, “Pakistan’s economy is stuck in a low-growth trap, with poor human development and rising poverty.”. In April 2025, Army Chief General Asim Munir met a US congressional delegation. Regional integration, especially trade with India, could help Pakistan grow faster. Historical tensions kept commerce negligible. India must accelerate reforms. Strengthening ties with the EU and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) can reduce dependence on US-China dynamics. India’s strategic balance between Washington and Beijing cements its place in a multipolar world. Pakistan faces a tougher climb. Reviving the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (Saarc) or exploring the Indian trade could anchor it regionally. Deglobalisation’s pressures add urgency to these reforms.
