content: Ambas plataformas subirán sus precios en Estados Unidos desde el 25 de abril. Los aranceles del 145 % y el fin de exenciones fiscales afectan su modelo de ...
resumen:
Temu y Shein subirán sus precios en Estados Unidos a partir del 25 de abril.
La decisión responde a las nuevas medidas arancelarias impuestas por el presidente Donald Trump a los productos fabricados en China.
El nuevo paquete incluye un arancel del 145 % sobre gran parte de las importaciones chinas, así como la eliminación de la exención fiscal que aplicaba a productos de menos de 800 dólares.
Ambas compañías aprovecharon esa exención —conocida como “disposición de minimis”— para enviar millones de paquetes sin pagar aranceles.
Esa ventaja desaparecerá el 2 de mayo.
Temu aseguró que se ha reabastecido con anticipación y que hará “todo lo posible por mantener los precios bajos”.
También está invirtiendo en almacenes dentro de Estados Unidos.
Shein ha acelerado la expansión de centros de distribución en suelo estadounidense.
Ambas empresas figuran entre las que más invirtieron en publicidad digital el año pasado.
Tras el anuncio de las nuevas tarifas, han reducido su presencia publicitaria en plataformas como Facebook, Instagram, TikTok y X, según datos de la firma Sensor Tower.
Pekín impuso nuevos aranceles a productos estadounidenses de hasta un 125 %.
China ordenó a sus aerolíneas no aceptar más entregas de aviones Boeing.
Los consumidores en Estados Unidos comenzarán a notar los incrementos en los próximos días.
Ambas compañías recomendaron aprovechar los precios actuales antes del 25 de abril.

content: China no se quedó de brazos cruzados ante la ofensiva arancelaria de Trump y replicó con impuestos del 125% para las importaciones estadounidenses.
resumen: Los aranceles estadounidenses no impedirán que las plataformas digitales Shein y Temu vendan sus productos en Estados Unidos. El presidente Donald Trump impuso aranceles adicionales del 20% sobre los productos importados de China. Washington también sugirió que se podría poner fin a una regla que permitía importar paquetes por un valor inferior a 800 dólares sin pagar gravámenes. Shein y Temu se aprovecharon durante años de esta norma y pudieron enviar productos por un valor de decenas de miles de millones de dólares a Estados Unidos. China replicó con impuestos del 125% para las importaciones estadounidenses. title: Cinco regiones superan los US$ 900 millones en exportaciones al primer bimestre - (Published 15 hour(s), 20 minute(s) ago)
content: ADEX informó que las exportaciones regionales crecieron 26.2% y sumaron US$ 10,298 millones hasta febrero. ¿Qué regiones lideraron los envíos al exterior?
resumen:
Las exportaciones de las regiones del Perú, sin considerar Lima y Callao, sumaron US$ 10,298 millones en los dos primeros meses de 2025, lo que representa un incremento de 26.2% respecto al mismo periodo del año anterior, según la Asociación de Exportadores (ADEX).

Del total exportado, US$ 8,104 millones correspondieron a productos tradicionales, con un aumento de 27.8%. El sector minero lideró con US$ 7,394 millones, un 26.7% más que en el mismo periodo del año pasado. También se registraron alzas en hidrocarburos (37.5%) y pesca primaria (117%). En contraste, los envíos agro tradicionales cayeron 40.2%.

Las exportaciones no tradicionales alcanzaron los US$ 2,194 millones, con un crecimiento de 20.7%. Este resultado estuvo impulsado principalmente por el rubro agroindustrial, que subió de US$ 1,319 millones a US$ 1,699 millones. Otros sectores como siderometalurgia (67.1%), metalmecánica (22.8%) y textil (1.3%) también mostraron aumentos. Sin embargo, seis de los diez rubros no tradicionales presentaron caídas, entre ellos madera (-14.6%), confecciones (-9.9%) y químico (-10.6%).

Ica encabezó el ranking regional con exportaciones por US$ 1,822 millones (7.8% más), principalmente por envíos de uvas, cobre y hierro. Le siguieron Arequipa (US$ 1,146 millones, +32%), Moquegua (US$ 1,103 millones, +34.3%) y Áncash (US$ 962 millones, +17.3%). Puno ocupó el quinto lugar con US$ 886 millones, registrando el mayor crecimiento porcentual (75.4%).

Otras regiones que destacaron por su fuerte expansión en valores relativos fueron Huánuco (443.8%), San Martín (130.7%), Junín (101.2%) y Ayacucho (85.3%).

En total, 19 regiones reportaron resultados positivos. Por el contrario, La Libertad, Cusco, Cajamarca y Huancavelica registraron caídas en sus exportaciones.

China, Estados Unidos, Emiratos Árabes Unidos, Canadá, Suiza e India fueron los principales mercados para los productos exportados desde las regiones.

title: EEUU anuncia nuevas tarifas portuarias a barcos vinculados a China - (Published 15 hour(s), 44 minute(s) ago)
content: Washington anunció nuevas tarifas portuarias sobre buques construidos y operados por China que atraquen en puertos estadounidenses, en una apuesta por impulsar la industria naval nacional y frenar el ...
resumen:
Washington anunció nuevas tarifas portuarias sobre buques construidos y operados por China que atraquen en puertos estadounidenses, en una apuesta por impulsar la industria naval nacional y frenar el dominio del gigante asiático en el sector.

Bajo las nuevas reglas, se aplicarán tarifas por tonelada o por contenedor, y se cobrarán por cada visita a Estados Unidos.

Se impondrán hasta un máximo de cinco veces al año y los propietarios podrán verse eximidos si hacen un pedido de un buque construido en Estados Unidos.

La medida se deriva de una investigación iniciada bajo el gobierno anterior de Joe Biden.

El representante comercial de Estados Unidos, Jamieson Greer, declaró que la mayoría de las tasas entrarán en vigor a mediados de octubre.

Para los barcos ensamblados en China, la tarifa empieza en 18 dólares por tonelada neta o 120 dólares por contenedor.

Además, todos los buques de transporte de automóviles que no hayan sido fabricados en Estados Unidos también tendrán que pagar una tasa que comenzará a aplicarse dentro de 180 días.

El anuncio introduce también nuevos recargos para los barcos de transporte de gas natural licuado, aunque no entrarán en vigor hasta dentro de tres años.

Una hoja informativa que acompaña al anuncio dice que las tasas no cubrirán “el transporte marítimo en los Grandes Lagos o el Caribe, el transporte marítimo hacia y desde los territorios de Estados Unidos, o las exportaciones de productos básicos en buques que llegan vacíos a Estados Unidos”.

Según Lin Jian, un portavoz del Ministerio chino de Relaciones Exteriores, las nuevas tarifas estadounidenses serán “perjudiciales para todos”.

title: WTO warns of 80% trade decline between US and China - (Published 17 hour(s), 44 minute(s) ago)
content: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has issued a stark warning, predicting that trade between the US and China could plummet by as much as 80%.
resumen: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has issued a warning, predicting that trade between the United States and China could plummet by as much as 80% this year due to escalating tariff tensions. Both countries are vital trading partners for South Africa. In its latest Global Trade Outlook and Statistics report, the WTO emphasizes that rising tariff conflicts could force countries into one of two increasingly isolated economic blocs. In 2024, total goods trade between South Africa and the US amounted to $20.5 billion, with South Africa exporting $14.7 billion and importing $5.8 billion. The automotive industry alone saw South Africa export approximately $1.8 billion worth of vehicles to the US. Bilateral trade between South Africa and China reached a record $34.18 billion in 2023, an increase from $1.34 billion in 2000. South Africa primarily exports mineral products to China. Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Lweala stressed that the growing trade tensions between the US and China could disrupt global supply chains and stifle worldwide economic growth. "We currently estimate that merchandise trade between the US and China will fall by 81% — a drop that would have reached 91% without recent exemptions for products like smartphones,” Okonjo-Lweala said. "If this leads to broader fragmentation of the global economy along geopolitical lines into two isolated blocs, our estimates suggest global real GDP could drop by nearly 7% in the long term,” she warned. Okonjo-Lweala further voiced concerns over the uncertainty surrounding trade policy, particularly in light of the US-China standoff.

He said Japan talks saw "big progress," though Japan's Finance Minister Katsunobu Kato expressed concerns over the global economic fallout. He described a call with Mexico's president Claudia Sheinbaum "very productive," and met with Italy Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni too. Meanwhile, Chinese state media on Thursday reported that Nvidia (NVDA) CEO Jensen Huang visited Beijing on Thursday amid growing concerns over US-China trade tensions. The visit follows the company’s disclosure of a $5.5 billion loss due to the US government’s unexpected new restrictions on semiconductor exports to China. AMD (AMD) and ASML (ASML) have also highlighted the uncertainty and costs to come from the tariffs. Pressure on US stocks has continued this week as Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell discussed the "challenging scenario" that tariffs could inflict on the economy. China has shown openness to trade talks with the US, contingent on specific conditions, despite the White House clarifying that "China now faces tariffs of up to 245% on imports to the United States." The tit-for-tat between the world's two largest economies has intensified: China raised its duties on imports of US goods to 125% from 84%, while US tariffs on Chinese imports have ballooned — to "a 125% reciprocal tariff, a 20% tariff to address the fentanyl crisis, and Section 301 tariffs on specific goods, between 7.5% and 100%." US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told Yahoo Finance on Tuesday that he was optimistic about "clarity" on tariffs and progress on key trade deals. Investors are also focused on possible delays and exemptions: Trump has signaled a possible delay to auto levies after suspending duties on some consumer tech, even as he insists these tariffs will eventually come to fruition. The baseline 10% tariff that went into effect on April 5 remains in place for all affected imports into the US. Trump says he doesn't want to keep raising tariffs on China. President Trump, speaking at the Oval Office, said that China had reached out to the US to negotiate on trade and that he viewed hiking tariffs on the country any further unfavorably. Trump offered an update on negotiations with the US's trading partners during the 90-day pause on his additional reciprocal tariffs. "We're doing very well with negotiations, I think, with all countries," Trump said to reporters after meeting with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni on Thursday. "We have a lot of countries that want to make a deal. Frankly, they want to make deals more than I do." Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent also chimed in, highlighting recent talks with Japan, the EU, South Korea, and India. "We're working on the big 15 economies," Bessent said. "First, we had a fantastic meeting with Japan yesterday. I believe there's been calls with the EU already, and then we have South Korea coming in next week, and I believe India is also talking. That's moving very quickly." Boeing (BA) planes in China are sitting in limbo after Beijing reportedly told Chinese airlines not to take further deliveries of the US jet maker's planes on Tuesday. Canadians poured a record $21.5 billion into US stocks in February, Bloomberg News reported Thursday, despite growing calls to boycott American goods and travel. At the same time, Canadians sold $1.45 billion worth of non-US. shares, signaling a strong preference for US markets even as public sentiment soured amid President Trump’s trade threats, the report explained. President Trump, searching for deals with key trade partners amid a broad pause in instituting his sweeping tariffs, hailed what he described as progress on several fronts. He posted on Truth Social that he had a "very productive call" with Mexico President Claudia Sheinbaum on Wednesday, and noted that he is set to meet with Italy Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni today. Meanwhile, he also described a trade meeting with Japanese representatives yesterday as "very productive." Japan Finance Minister Katsunobu Kato has expressed concerns over the global economic fallout from the US levies. France's Hermes (RMS.PA) announced on Thursday that it will pass the full impact of tariffs onto its affluent US customers, following a first-quarter sales report that slightly fell short of market expectations that marked an unusual dip in performance. Hong Kong’s postal service will stop handling shipments to and from the US in retaliation for President Trump's decision to eliminate the “de minimis exception,” which allowed goods worth $800 or less to be shipped to the US without tariffs. This move, effective April 27, impacts both sea and air shipments, forcing individuals and businesses to rely on private couriers like DHL, FedEx (FDX), and UPS (UPS), driving up costs. The US introduced new tariffs of up to 120% on goods previously covered by the exemption, further escalating trade tensions. Hong Kong’s government condemned the US actions as “unreasonable” and warned of rising costs for consumers. Japan's exports climbed for a sixth consecutive month in March, according to data released Thursday, as firms rushed to boost shipments ahead of potential US tariffs — raising fresh worries about the future of the country’s trade-driven economy. Japan voiced strong concern on Thursday over the global economic risks posed by US President Donald Trump's trade tariffs, with Finance Minister Katsunobu Kato issuing the government’s most pointed warning yet as talks with the US got underway. Chinese President Xi Jinping championed regional unity during his Southeast Asia visit, urging countries to embrace the idea of an 'Asian family' — a move seen as a pushback against US efforts to curb trade links with Beijing. With 25% tariffs on imported autos and certain auto parts, automakers have been grappling with how to manage higher trade-related costs. Korean automaker Hyundai, which has been localizing production for some time, told Yahoo Finance it will shield consumers from price increases for now. Stocks fell to session lows after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said the Fed faces a "challenging scenario" if tariffs create higher inflation and lower US growth. The benchmark S&P 500 (^GSPC) dropped about 2.4%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) shed more than 600 points, or around 1.6%. And the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) fell 3.6%. Fed Chair Powell used the example of cars to illustrate how a one-time supply shock could lead to more persistent inflation. Powell said that he has heard from CEOs of "significant companies" that uncertainty around importing components "is just a huge issue" right now. title: Trump tariffs impact markets and economy. Should Congress intervene? | Opinion - (Published 22 hour(s), 26 minute(s) ago)
content: Under the U.S. Constitution, Congress directly holds the power to impose and collect tariffs. What's stopping Congress from intervening now?
resumen: Under the U.S. Constitution, Congress directly holds the power to impose and collect tariffs. Article I, Section 8 grants Congress the authority "to lay and collect Taxes, Duties, Imposts and Excises" and "to regulate Commerce with foreign Nations." Much of the authority of the President in this area is a result of the Congress delegating its own authority through the passage of laws. The current law provides specific conditions under which the President can modify tariffs but usually require some form of justification. The Reciprocal Tariff Act of 1934 allowed the President to negotiate tariff reductions. In 1962, Congress gave the President the ability to adjust tariffs if imports were deemed a threat to national security. The Trade Act of 1974 permits tariff adjustments in response to unfair trade practices by foreign governments. In times of national emergencies, the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 gives the President broad authority to restrict trade. Executive actions can and are regularly challenged in the U.S. courts. Judges generally uphold presidential actions if they stay within the boundaries set by Congress. In United States v. Yoshida International, Inc. (1975), a court examined whether an import surcharge proclaimed by the President was legally permissible under federal law. The court noted, “In a statute dealing with foreign affairs, a grant to the President which is expansive to the reader's eye should not be hemmed in or 'cabined, cribbed, confined' by anxious judicial blinders.” Kevin Wagner is a noted constitutional scholar and political science professor at Florida Atlantic University.

title: What Bangladesh stands to gain from withdrawal of US sanctions on Russia - (Published 16 hour(s), 41 minute(s) ago)
content: While President Trump can ease most US sanctions on Russia as part of the Black Sea Deal, severe restrictions require Congress approval, and international sanctions need global cooperation. If enacted ...
resumen:
On April 18, 2025, The Business Standard published an analysis on what Bangladesh stands to gain from the withdrawal of US sanctions on Russia.

If the Black Sea ceasefire deal is enacted, it could resolve complex issues like Rooppur loan repayments for Bangladesh, as well as lower food, fertiliser, and fuel prices.

The Black Sea ceasefire would ease Bangladesh's trade with the warring nations, cutting freight costs. Fuel prices are expected to drop, dragging down LNG, coal, food, and fertiliser prices — saving foreign currency and boosting Bangladesh's economy.

The Kremlin demands a pause in Black Sea fighting, contingent on lifting sanctions on Rosselkhozbank and other financial institutions involved in global food trade, including fish and fertilisers, and reconnecting them to SWIFT. All restrictions on food, fertilisers, ships, and agricultural machinery must also be lifted.

Following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the US and allies imposed extensive sanctions to hinder Moscow's war efforts. President Trump seeks to end the conflict. While Trump can lift most US sanctions independently, Congress approval is needed for the severest restrictions, and international sanctions require global cooperation.

Bangladesh imports several products from both Russia and Ukraine, such as crude oil, food grains, fertilisers, metals, and chemicals. If the ceasefire deal takes effect, prices of these products will decline.

The Kremlin put forward certain demands, including lifting US and EU sanctions on Russian institutions involved in trade, restoring their SWIFT access, and removing all restrictions on food, fertilisers, ships, and agricultural machinery.

The European Union (EU) said the withdrawal of all Russian forces from Ukraine would be one of the main conditions to lift or amend EU sanctions on Russia.

If sanctions on Russian oil exports are lifted and the US increases oil production as promised, oil prices in the international market could return to pre-war levels. This would greatly benefit Bangladesh.

The deal will have a ripple effect on Bangladesh's economy — government subsidies on electricity and fuel will decrease, transportation costs in the private sector will fall, and it will strengthen Bangladesh's forex reserves while stabilising the exchange rate.

The Russia-Ukraine war disrupted Bangladesh's imports, particularly wheat and fertilisers, which led to high prices.

US sanctions on Russian banks further complicated transactions for the $12 billion Rooppur Nuclear Power Plant, 90% of which is financed by Russia. Bangladesh now owes Russia over $1 billion in interest and fees, delaying the project. Recent payment attempts through Sonali Bank were blocked by Standard Chartered Bank in New York.

The Rooppur loan transaction complications would be resolved if the US withdrew sanctions on Russian institutions. If the SWIFT transaction ban on Russia is lifted, payments for Rooppur can begin. If the US lifts sanctions on Rosatom, transactions can proceed smoothly. Rosatom, Russia's State Atomic Energy Corporation, is implementing the Rooppur power project.

Bangladesh's garment exports were also significantly impacted due to the war. Apparel makers have said nearly 4% of Bangladesh's garment export market is in Russia. Due to the Black Sea crisis, goods were rerouted through other countries to reach Russia, raising costs and reducing export volumes.

If the Black Sea issue is resolved, the struggling export market in Russia will revive, and garment exports will increase.

If the US lifts sanctions on Russia, Bangladesh's RMG sector will benefit significantly. In recent years, new markets for garment exports were emerging in Russia, but the war has put those prospects at risk.

Bangladesh imports a large quantity of food products from Russia and Ukraine. Importing from alternative countries has significantly increased prices, creating a food crisis. If the Black Sea becomes safe again, the additional costs will decrease, and imports and exports will return to normal.

Before the Ukraine-Russia war, the price of crude oil was below $50 per barrel. During the war, it rose to $130, and now it is around $70-72. If sanctions on Russian oil exports are lifted and the US increases oil production as promised, oil prices in the international market could return to pre-war levels.

If oil prices fall in the international market, LNG and coal prices will follow suit. Both the government and private sector in Bangladesh will significantly benefit. This will lead to lower energy and transportation costs for the private sector.

The Black Sea deal will have a significant impact on the global energy market and Bangladesh will benefit as well, since the country is fully dependent on imports for both refined and unrefined petroleum products.

The article was written by Shaikh Abdullah & Abul Kashem.

title: Fed chairman Jerome Powell warns of tariff strife as President Trump seeks lower interest rates - (Published 11 hour(s), 43 minute(s) ago)
content: President Donald Trump can't wait for Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell's "termination," after Chicago speech. Here's what's happening.
resumen: Trump calls for a decrease in interest rates as the Fed looks at what might need to happen to combat inflation. The next Fed meeting to discuss interest rates isn't until May. Trump looks forward to Powell's "termination" after Fed chairman warns of inflation as price changes occur due to tariffs. Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell and President Donald Trump are at odds over interest rates. One of the main issues of whether rates should be cut or not is Trump's tariffs. In remarks during an April 16 event, Powell stated that there was need for "greater clarity" on the on again, off again tariffs that has led to much worry among financial giants and Americans on whether or not they could lead the United States to a recession. "Unemployment is likely to go up as the economy slows, in all likelihood, and inflation is likely to go up as tariffs find their way and some part of those tariffs come to be paid by the public," Powell said April 16, in remarks to the Economic Club of Chicago. The remark may cost Powell his position if Trump has his way. Along with Powell's warning of what the tariffs could potentially mean for the public, he also said the Fed should be focusing on fighting inflation, which could mean a delay in interest cuts. In a post on Truth Social on Thursday, April 17, Trump criticized Powell as "too late" when making decisions, the remarks he made about Trump's beloved tariffs and the Fed not lowering interest rates. At the end, he calls for Powell's termination. "...(Powell) should have lowered Interest Rates, like the ECB, long ago, but he should certainly lower them now. Powell’s termination cannot come fast enough!" the president wrote early Thursday morning. During the Economic Club meeting, Powell stated that politics is not what the Fed looks at when making its decisions on interest rates. "People can say whatever they want," Powell added. "That's fine. That's not a problem. But we will do what we do strictly without consideration of political or any other extraneous factors." The Fed is the organization in charge of cutting or hiking up interest rates in the United States. Usually rates are cut to help stimulate a flagging economy and job market. They raise interest rates to help combat rising costs and inflation. Legally, no. Trump cannot fire Powell from his position. The Fed's independence is something that is part of congressional law. So unless Congress changes the law, Powell's job is safe. "So, you know, Congress could change that law. But, I don't think there's any danger of that," Powell said. "Fed independence has pretty broad support across both political parties and both sides of the Hill." Powel was appointed chair of the Fed in 2018 during Trump's first administration. He was reappointed for a four-year term in 2022. In general, one way to curtail inflation rates is by hiking up interest rates in hopes of balancing out, but by doing that there are a number of economic risks that could follow, including an increase in unemployment. The Federal Reserve has yet to raise interest rates, and in March announced that they will remain steady for now. CME FedWatch site, which monitors the Federal Reserve and estimates possible rate increases, shows around a 91% chance that the Federal Reserve will leave interest rates where they are at its next meeting in May, and only an 8.9% likelihood that interest rates will be eased.

title: The decoupling of China and the US amid the trade war - (Published 23 hour(s), 37 minute(s) ago)
content: The escalation of tariffs initiated by Donald Trump is setting the stage for a dramatic shift in the global economy with the irreversible distancing of the world's two leading industrial, ...
resumen:
The escalation of tariffs initiated by Donald Trump is setting the stage for a dramatic shift in the global economy with the irreversible distancing of the world's two leading industrial, technological and financial powers.

By Arnaud Leparmentier (New York (United States) correspondent) and Harold Thibault (Beijing (China) correspondent).

The divorce between Donald Trump's United States and China will be painful. By banning Nvidia, a leader in artificial intelligence chips, from selling even unsophisticated microprocessors to Beijing, the US president caused new tremors in the financial markets on Wednesday, April 16. Nvidia's stock fell by 6.9%, dragging down US tech stocks and the Nasdaq index, which lost 3.07%. The financial markets are making the Trump-driven Chinese-American decoupling very costly. Meanwhile, Chinese President Xi Jinping, by resisting, is working to increase this cost for the United States.

Already, Trump had to reluctantly suspend the tariffs on electronic devices produced in China as they threatened to sink Apple, which manufactures most of its iPhones in the country, and US electronics more broadly. However, he remained inflexible on the rest of Chinese imports, which have been taxed at a rate of 145% since April 10, a level that Beijing has not exactly matched in its response, which came in the form of 125% tariffs imposed on April 11. China has chosen to pull a series of levers, such as banning its airlines from receiving Boeing aircraft deliveries. Furious, Trump accused China of not honoring its contracts. More discreetly, Beijing has created a licensing system for exporting certain rare Earth metals, effectively suspending shipments of some of these strategic metals used to manufacture essential magnets in smartphones, medical imaging, electric vehicles and missiles.

title: Decoding China’s rise: USA at a crossroads - (Published 18 hour(s), 27 minute(s) ago)
content: This shift became particularly evident after 2016, when then-President Donald Trump adopted an aggressive stance on China. As Trump returns to power in 2025 with renewed determination to bring China ...
resumen:
China's journey to economic dominance has been a roller coaster of strategic manoeuvring. The United States criticized China for not aligning with the liberal, rules-based global order, rebuking Beijing's practices of protectionism, trade barriers, and heavy state intervention. The US achieved little success in forcing China to conform, and the US itself has begun to mirror many aspects of China's approach. This shift became evident after 2016, when then-President Donald Trump adopted an aggressive stance on China. As Trump returns to power in 2025, the US now resembles China more than ever. China is now dictating the next steps.

In the 1970s, Deng Xiaoping initiated market reforms, opening China to foreign investment. This approach was accelerated under President Jiang Zemin and Premier Zhu Rongji, who restructured the Chinese economy to align with capitalist practices, facilitating China's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2001. Western policymakers believed economic liberalization would lead to political reform. Under President Hu Jintao, China made a complete U-turn, emphasizing state intervention and prioritizing the creation of "national champions" through large-scale state subsidies. This trajectory has intensified under President Xi Jinping, who has accelerated China's dominance in critical technologies, industrial production, and export-led growth.

In 2004, China accounted for 9% of global manufacturing output; by 2023, this figure surged to 29%, according to a World Bank report. China's GDP grew from approximately $350 billion in 1989 to $1.66 trillion by 2003 and $17.79 trillion by 2023—second only to the United States. Despite US pressure, China has not yielded, refining its approach to dominate emerging strategic sectors. Economist Brad Setser points out that China's export growth is now three times the rate of global trade. China leads in automobile production, accounting for two-thirds of global demand. It dominates the supply of steel and aluminium and holds the largest rare-earth reserves, controlling approximately 90% of the separation and refining capacity. In shipbuilding, China's state-owned shipbuilder produced a larger tonnage of commercial vessels in 2024 than America has built since the Second World War. Chinese EVs are 50% cheaper than their US counterparts, and China accounts for 60% of global EV sales. This dominance extends to battery production, solar panels, and clean energy equipment.

Economist Jason Furman highlighted that the proportion of people working in manufacturing has been declining for decades and overall domestic industrial production remains stagnant. While the US appears poised to fully embrace protectionist policies, this approach carries risks. For US industrial production to thrive, the country needs consistent and stable trade and industrial policies.

China has executed precise and strategic manoeuvres that have bolstered its current standing on the global stage. According to findings published in the MIT Sloan Management Review (Spring 2025), Chinese companies face a threefold challenge in branching out globally: rising trade tensions with the US, new investment regulations imposed by other countries, and hurdles such as infrastructure deficits and adapting to unfamiliar cultures. China has taken a "place-based" approach to internationalization, focusing on microregions. A 2019 McKinsey study states that there are at least 40,000 microregions worldwide, each spanning around 3,000 square kilometres, with an average GDP of $3 billion and about 180,000 residents. Among the 2 billion people living in microregions that achieved high growth over the past 20 years, 1.1 billion were in China.

Chinese firms are using three key tactics to sustain global growth: finding new routes to existing markets, building regional hubs for emerging markets, and leveraging digital talent hubs. For example, a Nanjing-based company established a manufacturing facility in Vietnam's Binh Duong province. Cities like Singapore, Dubai, Addis Ababa, Nairobi, and Accra serve as operational bases. DeepSeek, the Chinese AI chatbot, is based in Hangzhou.

The US now reflects many of China's state-driven economic strategies. China's ability to navigate internal control while executing sophisticated external manoeuvres has strengthened its global position and forced the US into an uncomfortable paradox: to compete with China, America must become more like it.

title: Trade War to Weaken Global Growth and Increase Inflation, I.M.F. Warns - (Published 17 hour(s), 30 minute(s) ago)
content: Kristalina Georgieva, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, warned in a speech that protectionism erodes productivity.
resumen: The world economy is expected to grow slower this year and experience higher inflation than previously anticipated, according to new forecasts to be released by the International Monetary Fund. The growth projections, to be released early next week, will offer the clearest indication to date of the damage that President Trump’s economic policies are having on global output. Since taking office in January, Mr. Trump has imposed a wide range of tariffs on most of America’s trading partners, while ratcheting levies even higher on imports from China, Canada and Mexico. Kristalina Georgieva, the I.M.F. managing director, said on Thursday in a speech ahead of the spring meetings of the I.M.F. and the World Bank, “Our new growth projections will include notable markdowns, but not recession. We will also see markups to the inflation forecasts for some countries.” The European Central Bank on Thursday lowered interest rates, saying that “the outlook for growth has deteriorated owing to rising trade tensions.” Central bankers, finance ministers and other policymakers will gather in Washington next week. Ms. Georgieva was careful in her criticism of the Trump administration’s policies, which have created widespread uncertainty for businesses and are disrupting international supply chains. Ms. Georgieva said, “Ultimately, trade is like water. When countries put up obstacles in the form of tariff and non-tariff barriers, the flow diverts. Some sectors in some countries may be flooded by cheap imports; others may see shortages. Trade goes on, but disruptions incur costs.” Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, said on Wednesday that the U.S. central bank was similarly weighing how to navigate a situation where Mr. Trump’s tariffs could lead to slower growth and higher inflation. Mr. Powell said at the Economic Club of Chicago, “We may find ourselves in the challenging scenario in which our dual-mandate goals are in tension. If that were to occur, we would consider how far the economy is from each goal, and the potentially different time horizons over which those respective gaps would be anticipated to close.” On Thursday morning, Mr. Trump lashed out at Mr. Powell, saying that the Fed chair was wrong to not be lowering interest rates in the United States. Slower global growth is expected to take a particularly tough toll on developing countries. Ajay Banga, the president of the World Bank, this week urged developing countries to lower their trade barriers to avoid higher U.S. tariffs and to maintain their own regional trade relationships as the international commerce system comes under pressure. He also noted that he expected global growth to be weaker than previously projections this year. Mr. Banga told reporters on Wednesday, “Countries need to care about negotiating and dialogue. It’s going to be really important in this phase, and the quicker we do it, the better that will be.”

title: Europe Seeks a Direct Line to Trump, Skeptical That Aides Speak for Him - (Published 21 hour(s), 11 minute(s) ago)
content: Despite Europe’s size, economic might and longstanding alliances with Washington, Trump officials have made clear it is not a priority, European officials say.
resumen: For European allies of the United States, President Trump’s White House is structured like a court. Mr. Trump is the ultimate decision maker. In the first three months of this Trump presidency, getting through to the president himself is the Europeans’ goal. Some have succeeded, including Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy, who is expected to meet him at the White House on Thursday. The most efficient interlocutors are not traditional diplomats working through institutions, but special envoys and advisers like Elon Musk. It is never quite clear whether the messages get through to Mr. Trump, even if he is more likely to trust an old friend like Steve Witkoff, whom he has installed as a foreign policy negotiator, over the civil servants he disdains. European officials found Trump officials polite but consumed with fulfilling the president’s wishes and expressed little interest in their allies. American officials gave no heads up to key European nations about renewed talks last Saturday with Iran over its nuclear program. The European countries — Britain, France and Germany — were signatories to the 2015 nuclear agreement that the president later left, had been the instigators and intermediaries for that deal and have been trying themselves to advance negotiations on a new one. Europe is not a Trump priority. Mr. Trump sees Europe as a rival or even an adversary, believing that the European Union was created “to screw the United States.” The Trump administration is “not terribly interested in what the Europeans have to say.” The New York Times spoke to European officials in Berlin, Brussels, London, Paris, Rome and other capitals to get a sense of how they are interacting with the Trump administration. In private, the Europeans said, Trump officials are welcoming and say reassuring things about his commitment to Europe, NATO and collective defense. That has been true, the officials said, of those like Secretary of State Marco Rubio and even Vice President JD Vance. Meetings are “cordial,” one American official said. Mr. Rubio and Mr. Witkoff traveled to Paris on Wednesday for talks with French leaders about ending Russia’s war in Ukraine. It is never clear to allies whether either man has real power over foreign policy or trade. In public, their comments about allies can be searing, as a kind of bond with Mr. Trump, while European officials are keeping silent for the most part to avoid his ire. Allied officials said that they can talk — sometimes — to Trump appointees like Michael Waltz, the national security adviser, or special envoys including Mr. Witkoff or Keith Kellogg, but that they are busy with many tasks. Mr. Witkoff has no official counterpart in European countries, so consultations can be haphazard. Mr. Waltz has become more cautious even in private after the revelation that he inadvertently added a journalist to a Signal text chain of top Trump advisers, one official said. Traditional channels — through the State Department, embassies, the National Security Council — have proved more difficult for productive exchanges, partly because the Senate has confirmed so few high-ranking officials. Pentagon officials are especially careful in conversations with allies, the officials said, attributing that reticence to a fear of being fired. A senior British military official recently professed confusion about who was steering the Trump administration’s Indo-Pacific policy in the White House. Mr. Trump, who despises the collective power of the European Union and sees many NATO allies as freeloaders, maintains his mistrust of multilateral institutions, even those designed by Washington, as obstacles to American power. Mr. Rubio refused at the last minute to meet Kaja Kallas, the E.U. foreign and security chief who favors stronger resistance to Russia, when she flew to Washington in February to see him. Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, has failed in repeated efforts to meet Mr. Trump. Ms. Meloni, the only E.U. leader invited to Mr. Trump’s inauguration, tried for weeks before securing the White House meeting with Mr. Trump. Though the European Union has considerable heft in trade and regulations, Mr. Trump’s trade adviser, Peter Navarro, has regularly declined to meet European officials. Conversations on trade with Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick have been friendly and even sympathetic, but it has been clear to European officials that he does not speak for the administration — Mr. Trump alone is making policy decisions, and they may change without notice. Mr. Lutnick himself admitted to CBS News that he was more of a messenger than a decision maker. Maros Sefcovic, the E.U. commissioner for trade, met with Mr. Lutnick for two hours on Monday. NATO’s secretary general, Mark Rutte, succeeded in meeting with Mr. Trump in mid-March, after which he came away reassured, for now, about the president’s support for collective defense. While he will happily meet with Mr. Rubio and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, Mr. Rutte believes that his personal relationship with Mr. Trump — forged when he was the prime minister of the Netherlands — is the best and perhaps only guarantee of a fair hearing, officials familiar with his thinking said. NATO, which is popular among Americans, is also working to preserve those views in the face of Mr. Trump’s skepticism. European alliance officials who grew up viewing the United States as its core were recently surprised to be assigned to convince young Americans of its worth. Influencing Americans ages 18 to 30 was the No. 1 priority of an outreach campaign, running from March to May, according to a briefing document shared with The Times — to promote “enhanced awareness of NATO’s relevance & purpose to national security.” President Emmanuel Macron of France, who like Mr. Rutte has a long relationship with Mr. Trump, is said to be able to get Mr. Trump on the phone fairly easily, as is Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain. Mr. Starmer notably turned up at the White House in February with a formal invitation to Mr. Trump from King Charles III for a rare second state visit, and he has resolutely refused to criticize the president. Mr. Trump did not spare Britain from his basic 10 percent tariff. Britain set out to negotiate its own trade deal with the United States before Mr. Trump announced his tariffs. Mr. Lutnick, who has led the talks, has been very “broad brush” in his approach, according to a senior British official. Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative, is good on details, but has little clout internally. The Americans do not want the Europeans meddling in the relationship with Moscow, the officials said, and have resisted European demands to participate in negotiations on Ukraine and for U.S. involvement in any post-settlement security guarantees. In Mr. Trump’s world, Europe exemplifies the old consensus represented by former President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and should learn to take care of itself while Washington redefines the world. Anna Cavazzini, a German member of the European Parliament, said after a trip to Washington, “They think Europe is weak. Europe is built on cooperation. They are not interested in cooperation so much.”

title: The myth of the Western-maintained international rules-based order - (Published 23 hour(s), 26 minute(s) ago)
content: Despite liberal whining that Trump threatens the ‘international rules-based order,’ the historical record shows Western nations have repeatedly overthrown democracies, backed genocides and violated ...
resumen: The article discusses the "international rules-based order" and questions the West's role in maintaining it. It references articles and reports expressing concern about threats to this order, particularly from President Trump and President Putin. The article cites a definition of the order from the House of Commons International Affairs Unit, which includes international organizations, laws, regulations, and shared norms. It highlights the UN charter's principle of refraining from the use of force against any state's territorial integrity or political independence. The article then questions the historical accuracy of the West's adherence to this order, citing examples such as the US and Britain's support for Israel's actions in Gaza, the 2003 invasion of Iraq, Turkey's war against the Kurds, Operation Condor, the mass killings in Indonesia, and the overthrow of democratically elected leaders in Guatemala and Iran. It also mentions the US intervening in foreign elections at least 128 times between 1946 and 2014. The article quotes George Kennan's 1948 statement about maintaining the US's position of disparity and CIA whistleblower Philip Agee's comments on the CIA's disregard for democracy. It concludes by suggesting that those who uncritically repeat the idea that the West has played a key role in maintaining a "rules-based international order" are either ignorant of history or trying to deceive. The author is Ian Sinclair. The article references Peter Beaumont from The Guardian, Mark Curtis from Declassified UK, Dr. Jonathan Leader Maynard, Professor Greg Grandin from Yale University, Professor John Coatsworth, Dr. Jason Hickel, and Noam Chomsky.

content: El presidente Donald Trump dijo estar “100%” seguro de que habrá un acuerdo sobre aranceles con la Unión Europea, algo en lo que coincide con la jefa ...
resumen: El Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI) no prevé una recesión este año pese a los aranceles de Trump, pero sí menos crecimiento económico. Los aranceles aplicados por el presidente estadounidense provocarán una desaceleración, pero no se espera que la economía mundial caiga en recesión este año, confirmó este jueves el Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI). La directora del Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI), Kristalina Georgieva, anunció que los aranceles aplicados por el presidente Trump provocarán una desaceleración, pero no se espera que la economía mundial caiga en recesión este año. Georgieva explicó que las proyecciones de crecimiento son a la baja, pero no muestran una recesión. Trump ha establecido un mínimo universal de aranceles de al menos 10% a todos los productos que entran en Estados Unidos, en vigor desde el 5 de abril, y de hasta 145% a los chinos. La jefa del FMI subrayó que la tasa efectiva en Estados Unidos se ha disparado a niveles que no se habían visto en mucho tiempo. Diversos estudios estiman que los aranceles aplicados ahora en Estados Unidos rondan el 20%. China, la Unión Europea y Estados Unidos son los mayores importadores. Georgieva ve oportunidades siempre y cuando se responda con inteligencia, como construir una economía mundial más equilibrada y más resistente a las crisis. Esto significa la necesidad de que todos los países pongan sus asuntos en orden porque no hay espacio para posponer las reformas necesarias, especialmente en un mundo de mayor incertidumbre y confrontado a frecuentes shocks. Esto requiere una acción presupuestaria decidida para reconstruir el espacio financiero necesario y una senda de ajuste gradual que respete los marcos presupuestarios. También hay que compensar el hecho de que otros países están rezagados con respecto a Estados Unidos en términos de productividad. Entre las soluciones defendidas por la directora gerente del FMI destacan: reformas ambiciosas del sector bancario, de los mercados de capitales, de las reglas de competencia, del derecho de propiedad intelectual y una adaptación a los usos de la inteligencia artificial. Los países también deben corregir sus principales desequilibrios, en sus presupuestos en algunos casos, como en Estados Unidos o Francia, y en sus balanzas comerciales en otros como China o Alemania. En un mundo que ahora es multipolar, la prioridad más importante es garantizar que podamos cooperar, y el FMI debe desempeñar un papel como lugar esencial para el diálogo, concluyó Georgieva.

title: What is stopping Trump from exiling you to a foreign prison? - (Published 21 hour(s), 8 minute(s) ago)
content: The legal world has been on notice for a constitutional clash since Trump resumed office, meticulously analyzing a series of court rulings that challenge the White House.
resumen:
President Trump told reporters this week that he would carefully study the law before deciding whether to exile Americans accused of violent crimes to prisons overseas.

Trump shared a different message with El Salvador’s dictatorial president, Nayib Bukele, who has already built sprawling maximum security complexes in service of Trump’s scheme to deport noncitizens out of legal reach.

Trump told Bukele, “Homegrowns are next,” using a euphemism for U.S. citizens.

Constitutional scholars see no ambiguity in the consequences of the president’s latest threat. Trump’s plans to forcibly remove U.S. citizens abroad — under any circumstances — is the bright red line they have been waiting for.

Harold Koh, former legal advisor of the State Department and former dean of Yale Law School, said that the courts have made it clear that the president can’t ship people abroad and deny them liberty without due process of law, and then claim that he is powerless to effectuate their return, rendering the courts powerless to stop such illegal conduct.

Koh continued that nothing in the Constitution empowers the president to be Extraterritorial-Warden-in-Chief. He can’t secretly skirt the law enforcement process by shipping prisoners abroad without following carefully negotiated extradition treaties. The courts have jurisdiction over foreign affairs, and, as important, they have jurisdiction over him and his subordinates, who are in Washington, D.C.

Stephen Vladeck, a prominent Supreme Court scholar and professor at Georgetown University Law Center, said there’s no legal mechanism for “deporting” citizens. If he’s talking about sending citizens to serve prison sentences for crimes in a foreign prison, that’s something else entirely — for which there is precisely zero legal authority.

A Supreme Court ruling, Trop vs. Dulles, from 1958, found that stripping an American of their citizenship, or denying that citizen entry into their homeland, is barred by the 8th Amendment and would amount to “a form of punishment more primitive than torture.”

Ahilan Arulanantham, co-director of the Center for Immigration Law and Policy at UCLA School of Law, said the right of an American to remain in their country is “perhaps the only truly unconditional constitutional right.”

Jamal Greene, a professor at Columbia Law School, said there is “no constitutional or statutory authority for the president to expatriate U.S. citizens.”

The Trump administration deported a man with legal status in the United States from El Salvador, Kilmar Abrego Garcia, back to the country, after a court had ruled against doing so over fears for his safety.

The Supreme Court unanimously ruled the administration must work to “facilitate” his return.

David Strauss, a law professor at the University of Chicago, said the administration had created a false legal construct in arguing that courts cannot tell El Salvador, a foreign government, what to do with its nationals.

Sen. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) said the administration’s disregard of a Supreme Court order had created an emergency.

U.S. district judge, Paula Xinis, told the Justice Department this week that the administration had done “nothing” to work toward his return.

U.S. District Judge James Boasberg ruled Wednesday that “probably cause exists” to find Trump administration officials are in criminal contempt over their refusal to follow his orders.

Robert Weisberg, a professor at Stanford Law School, noted that the Supreme Court does have tools at its disposal to enforce its rulings, such as the issuance of injunctions on administrative actions and the deployment of U.S. Marshals.

Norm Eisen, co-founder of the States United Democracy Center and counsel for the House Judiciary Committee during Trump’s first impeachment trial, said that multiple mechanisms are still in place to enforce court rulings.

title: Los aranceles de Trump abren oportunidades en Latinoamérica, UE e India, según expertos - (Published 18 hour(s), 49 minute(s) ago)
content: EL NUEVO DIARIO, MADRID.-La agresiva política arancelaria de Donald Trump va dirigida principalmente a China, por ello los países latinoamericanos, cuyos principales socios comerciales son las dos ...
resumen: La agresiva política arancelaria de Donald Trump va dirigida principalmente a China, por ello los países latinoamericanos buscan reducir su dependencia de ambas potencias (Estados Unidos y China) y diversificar, abriendo oportunidades a potencias intermedias. La Unión Europea e India son dos de las mejor posicionadas, según Javier Fernández Aparicio, autor de un documento de análisis que publica el Instituto Español de Estudios Estratégicos (IEEE). Estados Unidos ve con preocupación el crecimiento de la presencia de China en Iberoamérica, que ha logrado superar a Estados Unidos como principal socio comercial en Brasil, Chile y Perú. China tiene acuerdos de libre comercio con Chile (que cuenta con el 34% de las reservas mundiales de litio), Costa Rica, Ecuador, Nicaragua y Perú, y ha fortalecido los lazos económicos con Argentina, Brasil, México, Perú y Venezuela. 22 países de América Latina y el Caribe han firmado acuerdos con China en el marco de las iniciativas de la Franja y la Ruta. Biden ya empezó a hablar de la necesidad de recuperar influencia en Latinoamérica, pero no con el tono de Trump, que quiere imponerse con medidas agresivas como los aranceles, que graban especialmente a China y a los países que actúan como intermediarios de la producción china o tienen una relación comercial estrecha con el gigante asiático. La amenaza de Trump de apoderarse del canal de Panamá ha sido mal recibida en Latinoamérica. La mejor alternativa es buscar nuevos socios para desacoplarse de China sin incrementar los negocios de Estados Unidos. La presencia de China está muy consolidada con inversiones, préstamos, contratos y acuerdos firmados, pero abre una ventana de oportunidad a las potencias medias o regionales como UE o India. La Unión Europea puede aprovechar la coyuntura para revertir la situación, aunque compite con otros países. El análisis del IEEE destaca a la India como bien posicionado porque comparte con Brasil varios foros internacionales, en especial los BRICS y el G20. La influencia de India en América Latina está a años luz de la de las grandes superpotencias, pero el país tiene mucho potencial de crecimiento y ha sabido utilizar el poder blando. India tiene una rivalidad geopolítica con China que agrada a Estados Unidos y a las potencias regionales de latinoamericanas. La debilidad de Latinoamérica reside en la falta de una política suprarregional. Javier Fernández Aparicio pone como ejemplo el gran puerto Chancay en Perú (cuyo mayor accionista es una empresa china), que Chile ve como una amenaza para las operaciones de sus puertos.

title: Oposición conmemorará en Costa Rica, EEUU y Europa aniversario de protestas contra Ortega - (Published 14 hour(s), 29 minute(s) ago)
content: San José, 17 abr (EFE).- La oposición nicaragüense en el exilio informó este jueves que conmemorará en Costa Rica, Estados Unidos y en países de Europa el séptimo aniversario de las manifestaciones qu ...
resumen:
La oposición nicaragüense en el exilio informó que conmemorará en Costa Rica, Estados Unidos y en países de Europa el séptimo aniversario de las manifestaciones que estallaron en abril de 2018 contra el Gobierno de Nicaragua que preside Daniel Ortega junto con su esposa, Rosario Murillo.

Las actividades en Costa Rica, Estados Unidos y Europa, en la que demandarán justicia para las víctimas, así como libertad y democracia para Nicaragua, incluyen misas, conversatorios, actos públicos y ferias culturales, de acuerdo con las convocatorias.

En abril de 2018, miles de nicaragüenses salieron a las calles a protestar por unas controvertidas reformas a la seguridad social, que, luego de la respuesta con la fuerza, se convirtieron en una exigencia de renuncia del presidente Ortega, de 79 años y en el poder desde 2007.

Las protestas dejaron al menos 355 personas muertas, según la Comisión Interamericana de Derechos Humanos (CIDH), aunque organismos nicaragüenses elevan la cifra a 684, mientras que Ortega reconoce que fueron «más de 300» y mantiene que se trató de un intento de golpe de Estado.

En Costa Rica, los nicaragüenses en el exilio convocaron para el 18 de abril a una concentración frente a la Catedral Metropolitana de San José para participar en el tradicional viacrucis, bajo el lema ‘El calvario de Cristo y su ejemplo, nos inspira’.

Para el domingo 27 de abril convocaron a una misa en la parroquia San Isidro Labrador, del cantón Vázquez de Coronado, provincia de San José, que estará dedicada a la «libertad de Nicaragua, en memoria de los asesinados, de los presos políticos, y en solidaridad con los exiliados y desterrados». Ese mismo día, en los alrededores de la parroquia, también se realizará un acto cultural y una feria, donde se entonará la misa campesina, interpretada por el cantautor nicaragüense exiliado Luis Enrique Mejía Godoy.

Para el martes 29 de abril se llevará a cabo en Costa Rica el coloquio titulado ‘Políticos y sociedad civil en estallidos sociales: Abril 2018 en Nicaragua’, de carácter privado y que será transmitido a través de redes sociales.

En Estados Unidos, los opositores nicaragüenses exiliados se autoconvocaron para el sábado 19 de abril a asistir, vestidos de azul y blanco, los colores de la bandera de Nicaragua, al Imagine Mosaic del Central Park -conocido como el Memorial a John Lennon- para conmemorar el séptimo aniversario de las protestas contra Ortega.

El 20 de abril también se llevará a cabo una misa en la parroquia Reina de la Paz, ubicada en la ciudad de Waterloo, Iowa, para rendir homenaje a las víctimas.

La diáspora nicaragüense en Miami se reunirá en la iglesia Santa Ágatha para rendir homenaje «a las víctimas de la represión y renovar el compromiso de los exiliados con la lucha por una Nicaragua libre y democrática”.

Para el miércoles 24 de abril están convocados a una eucaristía en memoria de las víctimas en la parroquia Santa Bárbara, ubicada en Hialeah, Florida.

Bajo el lema ‘Abril No Se Olvida’, los nicaragüenses realizarán un acto comunitario el jueves 26 de abril en Indianápolis.

En Europa las actividades conmemorativas serán el lunes 21 de abril en La Haya, Países Bajos, donde se convocaron los opositores nicaragüenses para exigir “justicia y libertad”; y el domingo 27 de abril con una misa en la Iglesia St. Elisabeth, de Hamburgo, Alemania, seguida de una feria cultural.

title: Un contexto global que favorece la aprobación del acuerdo UE-Mercosur deja a Francia bajo presión - (Published 17 hour(s), 17 minute(s) ago)
content: El agravamiento generalizado de las tensiones comerciales transatlánticas impulsó a la UE a diversificar sus asociaciones de comercio y reforzó la postura de quienes defienden la aprobación del acuerd ...
resumen:
El agravamiento de las tensiones comerciales transatlánticas impulsó a la UE a diversificar sus asociaciones de comercio y reforzó la postura de quienes defienden la aprobación del acuerdo con el Mercosur, dejando a Francia bajo presión.

La crisis desatada por la nueva política arancelaria de Estados Unidos colocó bajo incertidumbre el futuro del intercambio comercial, equivalente a aproximadamente 1,8 billones de dólares.

La UE se lanzó a buscar nuevos socios comerciales, incluyendo a China y los cuatro miembros fundadores del Mercosur (Argentina, Brasil, Paraguay y Uruguay).

El próximo jefe de gobierno de Alemania, Friedrich Merz, dijo que los europeos necesitan nuevos socios comerciales muy rápidamente.

El acuerdo comercial entre la UE y el Mercosur comenzó a ser negociado hace poco más de 25 años, y en diciembre pasado los dos bloques anunciaron un entendimiento político sobre el contenido de los documentos.

Francia mantiene su oposición al acuerdo, por el impacto que tendría sobre el sector agrícola.

La Comisión Europea aún tiene que definir el mecanismo para la aprobación y ratificación.

Merz sugirió que el presidente de Francia, Emmanuel Macron, aún podía ser convencido a respaldar el acuerdo.

Una fuente diplomática francesa dijo que el texto «no ha cambiado y por lo tanto es inaceptable tal como está».

Un vocero de la Comisión dijo que las asociaciones con aliados de confianza con reglas definidas son más valiosas que nunca.

Alemania apoya la aprobación del acuerdo, consciente de su necesidad de obtener nuevos mercados.

La ministra francesa de Agricultura, Annie Genevard, admitió que la diferencia de postura se había tornado una fuente de malestar entre Francia y Alemania.

Genevard dijo que está fuera de cualquier consideración la posibilidad de «sacrificar la agricultura francesa en el altar de un acuerdo a cualquier costo».

El gobernador del Banco Central del país, François Villeroy de Galhau, informó a Macron que el acuerdo podría «amortiguar aún más los impactos arancelarios vinculados a la política comercial de Estados Unidos».

España y Portugal apoyan públicamente y con firmeza la aprobación y ratificación del acuerdo.

Polonia, un país de fuerte base agrícola, tampoco esconde sus reservas, y es el más fuerte aliado de Francia.

Polonia ocupa en el primer semestre de 2025 la presidencia semestral rotativa de la UE, y no ha impulsado discusiones de fondo sobre el tema.

Dinamarca ocupará esa presidencia en el segundo semestre, cuando se espera que se complete la revisión legal de los documentos y su traducción a los idiomas oficiales.

Austria había expresado reticencias sobre el acuerdo con el Mercosur, pero ha dado muestras de un posible cambio de perspectiva.

El ministro de Economía austríaco, Wolfgang Hattmannsdorfer, dijo sobre el acuerdo que «lo necesitamos ahora», a pesar de que el gobierno de coalición en el país sigue siendo formalmente contrario a la idea.

La Comisión Europea estimó que se propone presentar un texto «antes del fin del verano» boreal (que va a julio a septiembre).

content: En opinión de Verónica Malo, una izquierda demócrata y civilizada es la que sabe reconocer el triunfo de quien gana de manera legal como fue el de Daniel Noboa en Ecuador.
resumen: En opinión de Verónica Malo, una izquierda demócrata y civilizada es la que sabe reconocer el triunfo de quien gana de manera legal como fue el de Daniel Noboa en Ecuador. Para Claudia Sheinbaum, una victoria trasparente (en Ecuador se publicaron las boletas) por 12 puntos porcentuales y verificada por observadores internacionales resulta “dudosa”. En Venezuela, con boletas en mano, el opositor González Urrutia ganó con 7,119,768 votos contra los 3,225,819 de Maduro. ¡Un 67% contra apenas el 30%! La hoy presidenta de México y el oficialismo aceptó lo dicho por Maduro, pese a que su gobierno nunca mostró al público las boletas electorales. Sheinbaum no quiere tener relaciones diplomáticas con un país que tuvo elecciones libres, democráticas y soberanas, pero no le molesta tener relaciones con la Cuba de Díaz-Canel, por ejemplo. Sheinbaum se ha alineado al eje Bolivariano, esto es, a lo más atrasado, autoritario, bananero y dictatorial de América. La declaración de Claudia Sheinbaum queda en la misma línea que Maduro, Díaz-Canel y Ortega (quienes no reconocieron el triunfo de Noboa). Pudo estar con la izquierda más congruente y pensante del continente como es Gabriel Boric de Chile, Lula de Brasil y Orsi de Uruguay.

title: Los aranceles de Trump abren oportunidades en Latinoamérica a la UE o India, según expertos - (Published 18 hour(s), 47 minute(s) ago)
content: La política arancelaria de Donald Trump va dirigida principalmente a China ofrece oportunidades a Latinoamérica y a la UE, según expertos.
resumen:
La agresiva política arancelaria de Donald Trump va dirigida principalmente a China, por ello los países latinoamericanos, cuyos principales socios comerciales son las dos potencias enfrentadas, buscan reducir su dependencia de ambas y diversificar, en una dinámica que abre oportunidades a potencias intermedias.

La Unión Europea e India son dos de las mejor posicionadas, según Javier Fernández Aparicio, autor de un documento de análisis que sobre este tema publica el Instituto Español de Estudios Estratégicos (IEEE).

Estados Unidos ve con preocupación el crecimiento exponencial de la presencia en Iberoamérica de China, que en los últimos años ha logrado superar a Estados Unidos como principal socio comercial en Brasil, Chile y Perú.

China tiene acuerdos de libre comercio con Chile -país que cuenta con el 34% de las reservas mundiales de litio-, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Nicaragua y Perú, y ha fortalecido los lazos económicos a través de asociaciones estratégicas integrales con Argentina, Brasil, México, Perú y Venezuela.

22 países de América Latina y el Caribe han firmado acuerdos con China, lo que ha facilitado inversiones y préstamos.

Biden ya empezó a hablar de la necesidad de recuperar influencia en Latinoamérica, pero nunca con el tono de Trump, que quiere imponerse con medidas agresivas como los aranceles, que graban especialmente a China y a los países que actúan como intermediarios de la producción china o tienen una relación comercial estrecha con el gigante asiático.

La amenaza de Trump de apoderarse del canal de Panamá «ha sido muy mal recibida en Latinoamérica».

La mejor alternativa es buscar nuevos socios para desacoplarse de China sin incrementar los negocios de Estados Unidos.

Esta opción es de difícil implementación a corto plazo, pero abre una ventana de oportunidad a las potencias medias o regionales con interés en la región como UE o India.

La Unión Europea, cuya presencia en Latinoamérica ha ido en retroceso en los últimos años, puede aprovechar la coyuntura para revertir la situación, aunque compite con otros países.

El análisis del IEEE destaca a la India como bien posicionado porque comparte con Brasil varios foros internacionales, en especial los BRICS y el G20.

La influencia de India en América Latina «está a años luz» de la de las grandes superpontencias, pero el país tiene mucho potencial de crecimiento y ha sabido utilizar el poder blando: la cinematográfica de Bollywood, la gastronomía y prácticas tradicionales como el yoga han ganado popularidad en América Latina en los últimos años.

India tiene una rivalidad geopolítica con China que agrada a Estados Unidos y, a su vez, también a las potencias regionales de latinoamericanas que ven paralelismo con sus intentos de mitigar el poder del vecino del norte.

Su debilidad reside en la falta de una política suprarregional.

Fernández Aparicio pone como ejemplo el gran puerto Chancay en Perú -cuyo mayor accionista es una empresa china-, que Chile ve como una amenaza para las operaciones de sus puertos.

title: Trump says he ‘couldn’t care less’ if foreign automakers raise prices due to tariffs - (Published Apr 17, 2025)
content: President Donald Trump told NBC News in an interview ... Until that time, USMCA-compliant auto parts will remain tariff-free. The president also said the tariffs would be permanent.
resumen:
En una entrevista telefónica con NBC News, el presidente Donald Trump dijo que no despediría a nadie involucrado en el chat grupal de Signal en el que se divulgaron inadvertidamente planes de ataque militar a un periodista y agregó que "no podría importarle menos" si los fabricantes de automóviles aumentaban los precios debido a los nuevos aranceles.

Trump dijo que "no podría importarle menos" si los fabricantes de automóviles aumentaban los precios después de anunciar que impondría aranceles del 25% a todos los automóviles de fabricación extranjera.

Trump dijo: "El mensaje es felicitaciones, si fabricas tu automóvil en los Estados Unidos, vas a ganar mucho dinero. Si no lo haces, probablemente tendrás que venir a los Estados Unidos, porque si fabricas tu automóvil en los Estados Unidos, no hay arancel".

Cuando se le preguntó si les dijo a los directores ejecutivos que no subieran los precios, como informó The Wall Street Journal, Trump agregó: "No, nunca dije eso. No podría importarme menos si suben los precios, porque la gente va a empezar a comprar coches fabricados en Estados Unidos".

Trump continuó: "No podría importarme menos. Espero que suban sus precios, porque si lo hacen, la gente comprará coches fabricados en Estados Unidos. Tenemos muchos".

Cuando se le preguntó si le preocupaba que subieran los precios de los automóviles, Trump dijo: "No, no podría importarme menos, porque si suben los precios de los automóviles extranjeros, comprarán automóviles estadounidenses".

Después de la entrevista, un asistente se puso en contacto con NBC News para decir que Trump se refería específicamente a los precios de los automóviles extranjeros.

NBC News informó esta semana que las autopartes extranjeras también serían gravadas con un 25% incluso si los vehículos en los que se instalan se ensamblan en el país.

Las empresas que importan vehículos en virtud del Acuerdo Estados Unidos-México-Canadá (USMCA) recibirán una consideración especial hasta que el gobierno establezca un proceso para cobrar los derechos del 25%, según la Casa Blanca.

Hasta ese momento, las autopartes que cumplen con el USMCA permanecerán libres de aranceles.

El presidente también dijo que los aranceles serían permanentes.

Trump dijo: "Absolutamente, son permanentes, claro. El mundo ha estado estafando a los Estados Unidos durante los últimos 40 años y más. Y todo lo que estamos haciendo es ser justos y, francamente, estoy siendo muy generoso".

El anuncio de los aranceles de Trump el miércoles se produjo pocas semanas antes de su "Día de la Liberación" previsto para el 2 de abril, cuando los aranceles sobre una variedad de bienes de consumo entrarán en vigor.

Trump dijo que no planea retrasar aún más la imposición de los aranceles del 2 de abril, y consideraría negociar sobre ese punto "solo si la gente está dispuesta a darnos algo de gran valor. Porque los países tienen cosas de gran valor, de lo contrario, no hay lugar para la negociación".

Trump dijo que no tiene planes de despedir a nadie después de la noticia de que el asesor de seguridad nacional Michael Waltz agregó a un periodista a un chat grupal de la aplicación Signal con miembros de alto rango de la administración Trump que estaban discutiendo planes para atacar a los militantes hutíes en Yemen a principios de este mes.

Trump dijo: "No despido a la gente por noticias falsas y por cacerías de brujas", calificando la historia de "noticias falsas" durante toda la entrevista.

Trump dijo que todavía confía en Waltz y en el secretario de Defensa Pete Hegseth, quien también estaba en el chat de Signal y envió una línea de tiempo detallada de los ataques planeados antes de que ocurrieran.

Trump agregó: "Creo que es solo una cacería de brujas y las noticias falsas, como ustedes, hablan de eso todo el tiempo, pero es solo una cacería de brujas, y no debería hablarse de eso. Tuvimos un ataque tremendamente exitoso. Atacamos muy duro y muy letal. Y nadie quiere hablar de eso. Todo lo que quieren es hablar de tonterías. Son noticias falsas".

Trump dijo que "absolutamente" ha tenido conversaciones reales sobre la anexión de Groenlandia, que actualmente es un territorio danés semiautónomo.

Trump dijo: "Obtendremos Groenlandia. Sí, 100%".

Agregó que existe una "buena posibilidad de que podamos hacerlo sin fuerza militar", pero que "no descarto nada".

El vicepresidente JD Vance visitó Groenlandia con su esposa, Usha, y habló con los miembros del servicio en la Base Espacial Pituffik, una base de la Fuerza Espacial de EE. UU. en la costa noroeste de Groenlandia.

title: Global trade takes a hit from Trump’s tariffs - (Published 22 hour(s), 10 minute(s) ago)
content: Forecasts from major international organizations warn of the impact of the US president’s economic policies on the exchange of goods ...
resumen:
Economic forecasts are attempting to put figures to the sense of anxiety the global economy is experiencing following Donald Trump’s crackdown on trade. The U.S. president’s aggressive tariff policy threatens to curb international trade, hinder economic growth, and fragment the economy.

The World Trade Organization (WTO) estimates that merchandise trade will decline by 0.2% this year due to new U.S. tariffs. The WTO, chaired by Nigerian President Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, published its new forecasts for world trade on Wednesday. The new estimate for 2025 is almost three percentage points lower than what it would have been without the recent changes. Okonjo-Iweala warned that the trade war between the U.S. and China risks dragging the world into a recession. She expressed concern about economic and geopolitical fragmentation, with a growing dissociation between Washington and Beijing that forces other countries to take one side or the other. If that happens, global production could fall by 7%.

World Bank President Ajay Banga warned this Wednesday that increased uncertainty and economic instability will weigh on the global economy. The head of the World Bank argued that trade tensions are causing economic agents to become more cautious, which could curb investment and purchasing decisions by businesses and households. Banga calls on countries to “sit down and negotiate as soon as possible to establish a dialogue on trade issues.”

The IMF also joined the chorus of voices warning this week about the impact of tariffs on global trade. The organization, chaired by Bulgarian President Kristalina Georgieva, is finalizing preparations for its major annual meeting in Washington. The report published this week by the Fund states that geopolitical risk could manifest itself in the form of trade tensions, such as tariffs, trade wars, and sanctions, could be imposed for geopolitical reasons and affect international relations and economic activity.

This economic instability will very likely lead the European Central Bank (ECB) to cut interest rates by a quarter of a point this Thursday, to 2.25%. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is advocating caution in these uncertain times. Powell emphasized the inflationary risks of tariffs and expressed his support for waiting for greater clarity on Trump’s erratic policies before deciding on the price of money. The level of the tariff increases announced so far is significantly larger than anticipated. The same is likely to be true of the economic effects, which will include higher inflation and slower growth. Both survey- and market-based measures of near-term inflation expectations have moved up significantly, with survey participants pointing to tariffs. The U.S. economy was growing strongly, with very low unemployment and inflation almost under control, but now uncertainty and instability are the dominant tone in the face of Trump’s chaotic measures and his constant rectifications and band-aids. Powell acknowledged Wednesday that the economy is “moving away” from both objectives. For now, he prefers to wait and see.

Peterson Institute economists David H. Feldman and Gary Clyde Hufbauer warn that Trump’s tariff drift “may be able to bully small nations that depend on us, but in the international power game the European Union, China, and Japan will push back with bad consequences for America. We risk reigniting the kind of zero-sum international trade aggression that characterized the period between the First and Second World Wars, a time when militarism led to a global cataclysm.”

title: He Planned Trump’s Tariffs the First Time. Here’s What He Thinks of the New Ones. - (Published 14 hour(s), 35 minute(s) ago)
content: Your gadgets might have gotten pricier. Your stocks might have tanked. But Wilbur Ross says it’s all a part of the plan.
resumen: Wilbur Ross, former commerce secretary during Trump’s first term, spearheaded the beginning of Trump’s long-term trade war, providing the groundwork for new tariffs on certain sectors (steel and aluminum) and against certain nations (China). Ross has been happy to defend Trump’s current trade policy to the media, dismissing fears of recession or foreign aggravation while insisting that the U.S. can win any trade war. Ross believes Trump is fine-tuning the broad brush he used in the beginning and is starting to deal with the logical exceptions that should be made. Ross thinks it’s a natural process. Ross believes Trump has concluded to take a very firm stand on China, and probably end up with them having much more punitive tariffs than other countries. Ross said the first administration was devoting a lot of time to figuring out what were the actual powers the president can use without going back to Congress. Ross said the steel and aluminum tariffs that he had provided the material for were litigated up to the Supreme Court. Ross said the state of California already has said it will bring litigation on some of the tariffs. Ross said the CHIPS Act provides all sorts of incentives to some of these same companies. Ross said he thinks [Trump] views, longer term, the tariffs as another mechanism also for helping them. Ross said the Biden administration had a sensible trade policy with China. Ross said the Biden administration’s most recent edicts on semiconductors basically prevented companies like Applied Materials and Lam Research from selling chips to China, but they didn’t do anything about the subcomponents of those advanced chips, for example, ceramics from Japan. Ross said he doesn’t think there’s the potential for many companies, both domestic and international, to view all this back-and-forth and end up more reluctant to build factories or invest here in the long term. Ross said he was a keynote speaker at an annual semiconductor industry meeting. Ross said the executives are all concerned, but they all understand why the endgame is what it really has to be. Ross said they would like to be patriotic, and their only concern is to make sure that the loopholes get closed. Ross said he absolutely does believe that the way Trump is imposing tariffs now will be conducive to bringing back manufacturing to the States, for gadgets, electronics, artificial intelligence. Ross said once Trump makes a deal with the first couple of big players, whether that’s Japan or Vietnam or whomever, he thinks then people will see there’s a path forward and he thinks markets will settle down. Ross said he thinks if they make it clear that you need to do this in order to get relief, then you could actually end up, longer term, with lower tariffs and lower nontariff trade values, not higher. Ross said there were plenty of nuances that all of them had. Ross said there’s only one person who’s elected president—that’s Trump. Ross said at the end of the day, it’s his view that it’s his call.
